<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In the first quarter 2008, fuel expense was $150.1&nbsp;million compared to $146.4&nbsp;million in the same
period in 2007. This increase was due to a $12.8&nbsp;million increase in the average cost of fuel,
partially offset by a $9.1&nbsp;million decrease related to total KWHs generated. The average cost of
fuel increased primarily due to coal purchased in the spot market at higher prices. See FUTURE
EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;FERC and Florida PSC Matters &#150; Fuel Cost Recovery&#148; herein for additional
information.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Non- affiliates</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In the first quarter 2008, purchased power from non-affiliates was $3.1&nbsp;million compared to $1.4
million in the same period in 2007. The increase was due to a $2.0&nbsp;million increase resulting from
the higher average cost per net KWH, partially offset by a $0.3&nbsp;million decrease in total KWHs
purchased.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Energy purchases from non-affiliates will vary depending on the market cost of available energy
being lower than Southern Company system-generated energy, demand for energy within the Southern
Company system service territory, and availability of Southern Company system generation.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Affiliates</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In the first quarter 2008, purchased power from affiliates was $8.7&nbsp;million compared with $7.0
million for the corresponding period in 2007. The increase was primarily the result of a $1.4
million increase resulting from the higher average cost per net KWH and a $0.3&nbsp;million increase in
total KWHs purchased.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->71<!-- /Folio -->

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>GULF POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The results of operations discussed above are not necessarily indicative of Gulf Power&#146;s future
earnings potential. The level of Gulf Power&#146;s future earnings depends on numerous factors that
affect the opportunities, challenges, and risks of Gulf Power&#146;s business of selling electricity.
These factors include Gulf Power&#146;s ability to maintain a stable regulatory environment that
continues to allow for the recovery of all prudently incurred costs during a time of increasing
costs. Future earnings in the near term will depend, in part, upon growth in energy sales, which
is subject to a number of factors. These factors include weather, competition, new energy
contracts with neighboring utilities, energy conservation practiced by customers, the price of
electricity, the price elasticity of demand, and the rate of economic growth in Gulf Power&#146;s
service area. For additional information relating to these issues, see RISK FACTORS in Item&nbsp;1A and
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL of Gulf Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the
Form 10-K.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Environmental Matters</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Compliance costs related to the Clean Air Act and other environmental statutes and regulations
could affect earnings if such costs cannot continue to be fully recovered in rates on a timely
basis. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;Environmental
Matters&#148; of Gulf Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the financial statements of Gulf Power under &#147;Environmental Matters&#148;
in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for additional information.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Eight-Hour Ozone Regulations</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;Environmental Matters &#150;
Environmental Statutes and Regulations &#150; Air Quality&#148; of Gulf Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for
additional information regarding revisions to the eight-hour ozone air quality standard. In March
2008, the EPA finalized its revisions to the eight-hour ozone standard, increasing its stringency.
The EPA plans to designate nonattainment areas based on the new standard by 2010, and new
nonattainment areas within Gulf Power&#146;s service territory are expected. The ultimate outcome of
this matter cannot be determined at this time and will depend on subsequent legal action and/or
future nonattainment designations and regulatory plans.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Carbon Dioxide Litigation</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">On February&nbsp;26, 2008, the Native Village of Kivalina and the City of Kivalina filed a suit in the
U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against several electric utilities
(including Southern Company), several oil companies, and a coal company. The plaintiffs are the
governing bodies of an Inupiat village in Alaska. The plaintiffs contend that the village is being
destroyed by erosion allegedly caused by global warming that the plaintiffs attribute to emissions
of greenhouse gases by the defendants. The plaintiffs assert claims for public and private
nuisance and contend that the defendants have acted in concert and are therefore jointly and
severally liable for the plaintiffs&#146; damages. The suit seeks damages for lost property values and
for the cost of relocating the village, which cost is alleged to be $95&nbsp;million to $400&nbsp;million.
Southern Company believes that these claims are without merit and notes that the complaint cites no statutory or
regulatory basis for the claims. The ultimate outcome of this matter cannot be determined at this
time.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->73<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>


<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>GULF POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Global Climate Issues</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;Environmental Matters &#150;
Global Climate Issues&#148; of Gulf Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for additional information
regarding executive orders issued by the Governor of the State of Florida addressing reduction of
greenhouse gas emissions within the state. On April&nbsp;30, 2008, the Florida legislature enacted
comprehensive energy-related legislation that includes authorization for the Florida Department of
Environmental Protection to adopt rules for a cap-and-trade regulatory program to address
greenhouse gas emissions from electric utilities, conditioned upon their ratification by the
legislature no sooner than the 2010 legislative session. This legislation, which has not yet been
signed by the Governor, also authorizes the Florida PSC to adopt a renewable portfolio standard for
public utilities, subject to legislative ratification. The impact of this legislation on Gulf
Power will depend on the development, adoption, legislative ratification, implementation, and
potential legal challenges in connection with rules governing greenhouse gas emissions and mandates
regarding the use of renewable energy, and the ultimate outcome cannot be determined at this time.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>FERC and Florida PSC Matters</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><I>Retail Fuel Cost Recovery</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Gulf Power has established fuel cost recovery rates approved by the Florida PSC. In recent
years, Gulf Power has experienced higher than expected fuel costs for coal and natural gas. If
the projected fuel revenue over or under recovery exceeds 10% of the projected fuel revenue
applicable for the period, Gulf Power is required to notify the Florida PSC and indicate if an
adjustment to the fuel cost recovery factor is being requested. Under recovered fuel costs at
March&nbsp;31, 2008 totaled $55.8&nbsp;million, compared to $56.6&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2007, and are
included in under recovered regulatory clause revenues on Gulf Power&#146;s Condensed Balance Sheets
herein. Fuel cost recovery revenues, as recorded on the financial statements, are adjusted for
differences in actual recoverable costs and amounts billed in current regulated rates.
Accordingly, any change in the billing factor would have no significant effect on Gulf Power&#146;s
revenues or net income, but would affect cash flow. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150;
FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;PSC Matters &#150; Fuel Cost Recovery&#148; of Gulf Power in Item&nbsp;7 and
Note 1 to the financial statements of Gulf Power under &#147;Revenues&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for
additional information.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>Income Tax Matters</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Bonus Depreciation</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">On February&nbsp;13, 2008, President Bush signed the Economic Stimulus Act of 2008 (Stimulus Act) into
law. The Stimulus Act includes a provision that allows 50% bonus depreciation for certain property
acquired in 2008 and placed in service in 2008 or, in certain limited cases, 2009. Gulf Power is
currently assessing the financial implications of the Stimulus Act and estimates the cash flow
reduction to tax payments for 2008 to be between $7&nbsp;million and $12&nbsp;million.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>Other Matters</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Gulf Power is involved in various other matters being litigated and regulatory matters that
could affect future earnings. In addition, Gulf Power is subject to certain claims and legal
actions arising in the ordinary course of business. Gulf Power&#146;s business activities are
subject to extensive governmental regulation related to public health and the environment.
Litigation over environmental issues and claims of various types,
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->74<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>


<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>GULF POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">including property damage, personal injury, common law nuisance, and citizen enforcement of
environmental requirements such as opacity and air and water quality standards, has increased
generally throughout the United States. In particular, personal injury claims for damages
caused by alleged exposure to hazardous materials have become more frequent. The ultimate
outcome of such pending or potential litigation against Gulf Power cannot be predicted at this
time; however, for current proceedings not specifically reported herein or in Note 3 to the
financial statements of Gulf Power in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K, management does not anticipate
that the liabilities, if any, arising from such current proceedings would have a material
adverse effect on Gulf Power&#146;s financial statements.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See the Notes to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for discussion of various other
contingencies, regulatory matters, and other matters being litigated which may affect future
earnings potential.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>ACCOUNTING POLICIES</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>Application of Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Gulf Power prepares its financial statements in accordance with accounting principles generally
accepted in the United States. Significant accounting policies are described in Note 1 to the
financial statements of Gulf Power in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K. In the application of these
policies, certain estimates are made that may have a material impact on Gulf Power&#146;s results of
operations and related disclosures. Different assumptions and measurements could produce estimates
that are significantly different from those recorded in the financial statements. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S
DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; ACCOUNTING POLICIES &#150; &#147;Application of Critical Accounting Policies and
Estimates&#148; of Gulf Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for a complete discussion of Gulf Power&#146;s
critical accounting policies and estimates related to Electric Utility Regulation, Contingent
Obligations, and Unbilled Revenues.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>Overview</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Gulf Power&#146;s financial condition remained stable at March&nbsp;31, 2008. Net cash provided from
operating activities totaled $49.8&nbsp;million for the first quarter 2008, compared to $33.4&nbsp;million
for the first quarter 2007. The $16.4&nbsp;million increase in cash provided from operating activities
in the first quarter 2008 was primarily due to an increase in cash flows from customer account
receivables and other current liabilities. Net cash used for investing activities totaled $78.9
million for the first quarter 2008 primarily due to gross property additions to utility plant of
$75.5&nbsp;million. These additions were primarily related to installation of equipment to comply with
environmental requirements. Net cash provided from financing activities totaled $28.8&nbsp;million for
the first quarter 2008, compared to $18.5&nbsp;million for the first quarter 2007. The $10.3&nbsp;million
increase in cash provided from financing activities in the first quarter 2008 was primarily due to
a $72.1&nbsp;million capital contribution from Southern Company in 2008 and a $20.8&nbsp;million increase in
cash flows related to notes payable, partially offset by an $80&nbsp;million common stock issuance to
Southern Company in 2007.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Significant balance sheet changes for the first three months of 2008 include a net increase of
$52.7&nbsp;million in property, plant, and equipment, primarily related to environmental projects, a
$13.2&nbsp;million change in energy-related derivative contracts, and the sale of a turbine rotor
assembly to Southern Power for $9.4&nbsp;million.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Capital Requirements and Contractual Obligations</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY<FONT style="font-variant: SMALL-CAPS"> &#150;</FONT> &#147;Capital
Requirements and Contractual Obligations&#148; of Gulf Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for a
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->75<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>


<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>GULF POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">description of Gulf Power&#146;s capital requirements for its construction program, maturities of
long-term debt, leases, derivative obligations, preference stock dividends, purchase commitments,
and trust funding requirements. Gulf Power had no maturities or redemptions of long-term debt in
the first quarter 2008. At March&nbsp;31, 2008 Gulf Power had no scheduled maturities of long-term debt
through March&nbsp;31, 2009.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Sources of Capital</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Gulf Power plans to obtain the funds required for construction and other purposes from sources
similar to those utilized in the past. Recently, Gulf Power has primarily utilized funds from
operating cash flows, short-term debt, external security offerings, and equity contributions from
Southern Company. However, the amount, type, and timing of any future financings, if needed, will
depend upon regulatory approval, prevailing market conditions, and other factors. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S
DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY &#150; &#147;Sources of Capital&#148; of Gulf Power
in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for additional information.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Gulf Power&#146;s current liabilities frequently exceed current assets because of the continued use of
short-term debt as a funding source to meet cash needs which can fluctuate significantly due to the
seasonality of the business. To meet short-term cash needs and contingencies Gulf Power had at
March&nbsp;31, 2008 approximately $5&nbsp;million of cash and cash equivalents and $125&nbsp;million of unused
committed lines of credit with banks. All credit agreements expire in 2008 and $100&nbsp;million
contain provisions allowing one-year term loans executable at expiration. Gulf Power expects to
renew its credit facilities, as needed, prior to expiration. See Note 6 to the financial statements
of Gulf Power under &#147;Bank Credit Arrangements&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for additional
information. These credit arrangements provide liquidity support to Gulf Power&#146;s obligations with
respect to variable rate pollution control bonds and commercial paper. Gulf Power may also meet
short-term cash needs through a Southern Company subsidiary organized to issue and sell commercial
paper and extendible commercial notes at the request and for the benefit of Gulf Power and other
Southern Company subsidiaries. At March&nbsp;31, 2008, Gulf Power had $19.4&nbsp;million of commercial paper
outstanding. Management believes that the need for working capital can be adequately met by
utilizing commercial paper programs and lines of credit without maintaining large cash balances.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Credit Rating Risk</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Gulf Power does not have any credit arrangements that would require material changes in payment
schedules or terminations as a result of a credit rating downgrade.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">There are certain contracts that could require collateral, but not accelerated payment, in the
event of a credit rating change to BBB- or Baa3, or below. Generally, collateral may be provided
for by a Southern Company guaranty, letter of credit, or cash. These contracts are primarily for
physical electricity purchases and sales. At March&nbsp;31, 2008, the maximum potential collateral
requirements at a BBB- or Baa3 rating were approximately $23.1&nbsp;million. The maximum potential
collateral requirements at a rating below BBB- or Baa3 were approximately $46.3&nbsp;million.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Gulf Power, along with all members of the Power Pool, is party to certain energy-related derivative
agreements that could require collateral and/or accelerated payment in the event of a credit rating
change to below investment grade for Alabama Power and/or Georgia Power. These agreements are
primarily for natural gas
and power price risk management activities. At March&nbsp;31, 2008, Gulf Power&#146;s total exposure to
these types of agreements was approximately $47&nbsp;million.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->76<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>GULF POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Market Price Risk</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Gulf Power&#146;s market risk exposures relative to interest rate changes have not changed materially
compared with the December&nbsp;31, 2007 reporting period. In addition, Gulf Power is not aware of any
facts or circumstances that would significantly affect such exposures in the near term.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Due to cost-based rate regulation, Gulf Power has limited exposure to market volatility in interest
rates, commodity fuel prices, and prices of electricity. To mitigate residual risks relative to
movements in electricity prices, Gulf Power enters into physical fixed-price contracts for the
purchase and sale of electricity through the wholesale electricity market. Gulf Power has also
implemented a fuel-hedging program with the approval of the Florida PSC.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The changes in fair value of energy-related derivative contracts and valuations at March&nbsp;31, 2008
were as follows:

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Gains and losses on energy-related derivative contracts related to Gulf Power&#146;s fuel hedging
program are initially recorded as regulatory liabilities and assets, respectively, and then are
included in fuel expense as they are recovered through the fuel cost recovery clause. Certain other
gains and losses on energy-related derivatives, designated as hedges, are initially deferred in
other comprehensive income before being recognized in income in the same period as the hedged
transaction. Gains and losses on energy-related derivative contracts that are not designated as
hedges are recognized in the statements of income as incurred.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">As part of the adoption of SFAS No.&nbsp;157 to increase consistency and comparability in fair value
measurements and related disclosures, the table above now uses the three-tier fair value hierarchy,
as discussed in Note (C)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein, as opposed to the previously
used descriptions &#147;actively quoted,&#148; &#147;external sources,&#148; and &#147;models and other methods.&#148; The
three-tier fair value hierarchy focuses on the fair value of the contract itself, whereas the
previous descriptions focused on the source of the inputs. Because Gulf Power uses
over-the-counter contracts that are not exchange traded but are fair valued using prices which are
actively quoted, the valuations of those contracts now appear in Level 2; previously they were
shown as &#147;actively quoted.&#148;
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">For additional information, see MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND
LIQUIDITY &#150; &#147;Market Price Risk&#148; of Gulf Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Notes 1 and 6 to the financial
statements of Gulf Power under &#147;Financial Instruments&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K and Note (F)&nbsp;to
the Condensed Financial Statements herein.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Financing Activities</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Gulf Power did not issue or redeem any long-term securities in the first three months of 2008. In
April&nbsp;2008, Gulf Power entered into a $110&nbsp;million term loan agreement that bears interest based on
one-month LIBOR and borrowed $80&nbsp;million under such agreement. Proceeds were used to repay a
portion of Gulf Power&#146;s short-term indebtedness and for other general corporate purposes, including
Gulf Power&#146;s continuous construction activities. In connection with the term loan agreement, Gulf
Power terminated $80&nbsp;million of derivative transactions at a loss of $5.2&nbsp;million. Gulf Power plans to borrow the remaining $30
million under the term loan agreement in June&nbsp;2008.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Also in 2008, Gulf Power converted its entire $141&nbsp;million of obligations related to auction rate
tax-exempt securities from an auction rate mode to other interest rate modes. Approximately $75
million of the auction rate tax-exempt securities were converted to fixed interest rate modes and
approximately $66&nbsp;million were converted to a daily floating rate mode.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In addition to any financings that may be necessary to meet capital requirements, contractual
obligations, and storm-recovery, Gulf Power plans to continue, when economically feasible, a
program to retire higher-cost securities and replace these obligations with lower-cost capital if
market conditions permit.
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->78<!-- /Folio -->

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>


<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="left">
<A name="136"></A>
</DIV>
<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>MISSISSIPPI POWER COMPANY</B></DIV>

<DIV align="left">
<A name="136"></A>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 0pt">MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="Center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">FIRST QUARTER 2008 vs. FIRST QUARTER 2007

</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>OVERVIEW</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Mississippi Power operates as a vertically integrated utility providing electricity to retail
customers within its traditional service area located within the State of Mississippi and to
wholesale customers in the Southeast. Many factors affect the opportunities, challenges, and risks
of Mississippi Power&#146;s business of selling electricity. These factors include the ability to
maintain a stable regulatory environment, to achieve energy sales growth, and to effectively manage
and secure timely recovery of rising costs. These costs include those related to growing demand,
increasingly stringent environmental standards, fuel prices, and major storm restoration.
Appropriately balancing required costs and capital expenditures with customer prices will continue
to challenge Mississippi Power for the foreseeable future.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Mississippi Power continues to focus on several key performance indicators. In recognition that
Mississippi Power&#146;s long-term financial success is dependent upon how well it satisfies its
customers&#146; needs, Mississippi Power&#146;s retail base rate mechanism, PEP, includes performance
indicators that directly tie customer service indicators to Mississippi Power&#146;s allowed return. In
addition to the PEP performance indicators, Mississippi Power focuses on other performance
measures, including broader measures of customer satisfaction, plant availability, system
reliability, and net income. For additional information on these indicators, see MANAGEMENT&#146;S
DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; OVERVIEW &#150; &#147;Key Performance Indicators&#148; of Mississippi Power in Item&nbsp;7
of the Form 10-K.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B><I>Net Income</I></B>

</DIV>
<DIV align="center">
<TABLE style="font-size: 10pt" cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%">
<!-- Begin Table Head -->
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD width="47%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="47%">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size: 8pt" valign="bottom">
    <TD nowrap align="center" colspan="3" style="border-bottom: 1px solid #000000">First Quarter 2008 vs. First Quarter 2007</TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size: 8pt" valign="bottom">
    <TD nowrap align="center"><I>(change in millions)</I></TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD nowrap align="center"><I>% change</I></TD>
</TR>

<!-- End Table Head -->
<!-- Begin Table Body -->
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD align="center" valign="top"><DIV style="margin-left:15px; text-indent:-15px">$(3.5)
</DIV></TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="center" valign="top">(17.6)</TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size: 1px">
    <TD colspan="3" valign="top" align="left" style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<!-- End Table Body -->
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Mississippi Power&#146;s net income after dividends on preferred stock for the first quarter 2008 was
$16.2&nbsp;million compared to $19.6&nbsp;million for the corresponding period in 2007. The decrease was
primarily a result of a $5.8&nbsp;million increase in non-fuel related expenses, a $2.5&nbsp;million increase
in depreciation and amortization primarily due to the amortization of regulatory items, a $1.0
million increase in regulatory liability for System Restoration Rider (SRR), and a $0.8&nbsp;million
increase in taxes other than income primarily due to franchise taxes, partially offset by a $3.5
million increase in territorial base revenues primarily due to a retail base rate increase
effective January 2008 and a $1.6&nbsp;million increase in other income and expense. For additional
information on SRR, see MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;PSC
Matters &#150; System Restoration Rider&#148; of Mississippi Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B><I>Retail Revenues</I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center">
<TABLE style="font-size: 10pt" cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%">
<!-- Begin Table Head -->

    <TD width="47%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="47%">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

    <TD nowrap align="center" colspan="3" style="border-bottom: 1px solid #000000">First Quarter 2008 vs. First Quarter 2007</TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size: 8pt" valign="bottom">
    <TD nowrap align="center"><I>(change in millions)</I></TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD nowrap align="center"><I>% change</I></TD>
</TR>

<!-- End Table Head -->
<!-- Begin Table Body -->
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD align="center" valign="top">$12.3
</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="center" valign="top">7.9</TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size: 1px">
    <TD colspan="3" valign="top" align="left" style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<!-- End Table Body -->
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In the first quarter 2008, retail revenues were $168.4&nbsp;million compared to $156.1&nbsp;million in the
same period in 2007.
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->84<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>

    <TD colspan="9" align="left" style="border-top: 3px double #000000">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<!-- End Table Body -->
</TABLE>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Revenues associated with changes in rates and pricing increased in the first quarter 2008 when
compared to the same period of 2007 due to a base rate increase effective January 2008 of $3.5
million and an increase in the ECO Plan rate effective April&nbsp;2007 of $1.8&nbsp;million. These increases
were partially offset by retail revenue reductions of approximately $1.0&nbsp;million related to SRR
revenues.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Revenues attributable to changes in sales growth increased in the first quarter 2008 when compared
to the same period in 2007 due to 3.3%, 2.1%, and 0.6% increases in KWH sales to residential,
commercial, and industrial customers, respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Revenues resulting from changes in weather were minimal because temperatures were essentially the
same during the first quarter of 2008 compared to the first quarter of 2007.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Fuel and other cost recovery revenues increased in the first quarter of 2008 when compared to the
same period in 2007 primarily as a result of higher fuel and purchased power expenses. Electric
rates include provisions to adjust billings for fluctuations in fuel costs, including the energy
component of purchased power costs. Under these provisions, fuel revenues generally equal fuel
expenses, including the fuel component of purchased power costs, and do not affect net income.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B><I>Wholesale Revenues &#150; Non-Affiliates</I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center">
<TABLE style="font-size: 10pt" cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%">
<!-- Begin Table Head -->
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD width="47%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="47%">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size: 8pt" valign="bottom">
    <TD nowrap align="center" colspan="3" style="border-bottom: 1px solid #000000">First Quarter 2008 vs. First Quarter 2007</TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size: 8pt" valign="bottom">
    <TD nowrap align="center"><I>(change in millions)</I></TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD nowrap align="center"><I>% change</I></TD>
</TR>

<!-- End Table Head -->
<!-- Begin Table Body -->
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD align="center" valign="top"><DIV style="margin-left:15px; text-indent:-15px">$7.5
</DIV></TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="center" valign="top">9.7</TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size: 1px">
    <TD colspan="3" valign="top" align="left" style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<!-- End Table Body -->
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Wholesale revenues from non-affiliates will vary depending on the market cost of available energy
compared to the cost of Mississippi Power and Southern Company system-owned generation, demand for
energy within the Southern Company service territory, and availability of Southern Company system
generation. In the first quarter 2008, wholesale revenues to non-affiliates were $84.8&nbsp;million
compared to $77.3&nbsp;million in the same period in 2007. The increase was due to increased revenues
from customers outside Mississippi Power&#146;s service territory of $4.7&nbsp;million and increased revenues
from customers inside Mississippi Power&#146;s service territory of $2.8&nbsp;million. The $4.7&nbsp;million
increase in revenues from customers outside Mississippi Power&#146;s
service territory was primarily due to a $4.3&nbsp;million increase associated with higher prices, a
$0.3&nbsp;million increase associated with increased sales, and a $0.1&nbsp;million increase in capacity
revenues. The $2.8&nbsp;million increase in revenues from customers inside Mississippi Power&#146;s service
territory is due to a $3.5&nbsp;million increase in fuel costs, partially offset by lower demand by
customers of approximately $0.7&nbsp;million.
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->85<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B><I>Wholesale Revenues &#150; Affiliates</I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center">

</TR>
<!-- End Table Body -->
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Wholesale revenues from affiliates will vary depending on demand and the availability and cost of
generating resources at each company within the Southern Company system. These affiliate sales are
made in accordance with the IIC, as approved by the FERC. These transactions do not have a
significant impact on earnings since the energy is generally sold at marginal cost. In the first
quarter 2008, wholesale revenues from affiliates were $28.4&nbsp;million compared to $18.9&nbsp;million in
the same period in 2007. The increase was primarily due to a $9.4&nbsp;million increase in energy
revenues, of which $9.2&nbsp;million was associated with higher fuel prices and $0.2&nbsp;million was
associated with increased sales. Capacity revenues increased $0.1&nbsp;million.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In the first quarter 2008, total fuel and purchased power expenses were $158.4&nbsp;million compared to
$135.1&nbsp;million in the same period in 2007. The increase in fuel and purchased power expenses was
primarily due to a $22.1&nbsp;million increase in the cost of fuel and purchased power and a $1.1
million increase related to total KWHs generated and purchased.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Fuel and purchased power transactions do not have a significant impact on earnings since the energy
purchases are generally offset by energy revenues through Mississippi Power&#146;s fuel cost recovery
clauses.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In the first quarter 2008, fuel expense was $130.1&nbsp;million compared to $121.7&nbsp;million in the same
period in 2007. The increase was primarily due to an $11.5&nbsp;million increase in the price of coal,
gas, transportation, and emission allowances, partially offset by a $3.1&nbsp;million decrease in
generation from Mississippi Power-owned facilities due to availability of lower cost affiliate
purchased power.
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->86<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>


<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>MISSISSIPPI POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Non-affiliates</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In the first quarter 2008, purchased power expense from non-affiliates was $2.3&nbsp;million compared to
$1.0&nbsp;million in the same period in 2007. The increase was primarily the result of a 115.5%
increase in the average cost of purchased power per KWH and a 9.7% increase in KWH volume
purchased.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Energy purchases from non-affiliates will vary depending on the market cost of available energy
being lower than Southern Company system-generated energy, demand for energy within the Southern
Company system service territory, and availability of Southern Company system generation.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Affiliates</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In the first quarter 2008, purchased power from affiliates was $26.0&nbsp;million compared to $12.4
million in the same period in 2007. The increase was primarily due to a 50.7% increase in the
average cost of purchased power per KWH as well as a 38.8% increase in KWH volume purchased
primarily due to reduced generation resulting in more purchased power needed to meet the gap
between generation and demand, and more sales outside the Southern Company system.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Energy purchases from affiliated companies will vary depending on demand and the availability and
cost of generating resources at each company within the Southern Company system. These purchases
are made in accordance with the IIC, as approved by the FERC.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B><I>Other Operations and Maintenance Expenses</I></B>

</TR>

$57.8&nbsp;million in the same period in 2007. The increase in other operations expense was primarily
due to a $1.8&nbsp;million increase in generation construction screening. The increase in maintenance
expense for the first quarter 2008 was primarily due to a $1.8&nbsp;million increase in distribution
maintenance, a $1.0&nbsp;million increase in expenses due to changes in environmental projects, a $0.9
million increase in production scheduled maintenance expenses, and a $0.6&nbsp;million increase in
company labor expenses across all functions.

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The results of operations discussed above are not necessarily indicative of Mississippi Power&#146;s
future earnings potential. The level of Mississippi Power&#146;s future earnings depends on numerous
factors that affect the opportunities, challenges, and risks of Mississippi Power&#146;s business of
selling electricity. These factors include Mississippi Power&#146;s ability to maintain a stable
regulatory environment that continues to allow for the recovery of all prudently incurred costs
during a time of increasing costs. Future earnings in the near term will depend, in part, upon
growth in energy sales, which is subject to a number of factors. These factors include weather,
competition, new energy contracts with neighboring utilities, energy conservation practiced by
customers, the price of electricity, the price elasticity of demand, and the rate of economic
growth in Mississippi Power&#146;s service area in the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina. For additional
information relating to these issues, see RISK FACTORS in Item
1A and MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL of Mississippi Power in
Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K.
</DIV>



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->88<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>



<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">


<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>MISSISSIPPI POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Environmental Matters</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Compliance costs related to the Clean Air Act and other environmental statutes and regulations
could affect earnings if such costs cannot continue to be fully recovered in rates on a timely
basis. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;Environmental
Matters&#148; of Mississippi Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the financial statements of Mississippi Power
under &#147;Environmental Matters&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for additional information.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Eight-Hour Ozone Regulations</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;Environmental Matters &#150;
Environmental Statutes and Regulations &#150; Air Quality&#148; of Mississippi Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form
10-K for additional information regarding revisions to the eight-hour ozone air quality standard.
In March&nbsp;2008, the EPA finalized its revisions to the eight-hour ozone standard, increasing its
stringency. The EPA plans to designate nonattainment areas based on the new standard by 2010, and
new nonattainment areas within Mississippi Power&#146;s service territory are expected. The ultimate
outcome of this matter cannot be determined at this time and will depend on subsequent legal action
and/or future nonattainment designations and regulatory plans.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Carbon Dioxide Litigation</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">On February&nbsp;26, 2008, the Native Village of Kivalina and the City of Kivalina filed a suit in the
U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against several electric utilities
(including Southern Company), several oil companies, and a coal company. The plaintiffs are the
governing bodies of an Inupiat village in Alaska. The plaintiffs contend that the village is being
destroyed by erosion allegedly caused by global warming that the plaintiffs attribute to emissions
of greenhouse gases by the defendants. The plaintiffs assert claims for public and private
nuisance and contend that the defendants have acted in concert and are therefore jointly and
severally liable for the plaintiffs&#146; damages. The suit seeks damages for lost property values and
for the cost of relocating the village, which cost is alleged to be $95&nbsp;million to $400&nbsp;million.
Southern Company believes that these claims are without merit and notes that the complaint cites no
statutory or regulatory basis for the claims. The ultimate outcome of this matter cannot be
determined at this time.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>FERC and Mississippi PSC Matters</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><I>Retail Regulatory Matters</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><I>Environmental Compliance Overview Plan</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See Note 3 to the financial statements of Mississippi Power under &#147;Retail Regulatory Matters &#150;
Environmental Compliance Overview Plan&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for information on
Mississippi Power&#146;s annual environmental filing with the Mississippi PSC. On February&nbsp;1, 2008,
Mississippi Power filed with the Mississippi PSC its annual ECO Plan evaluation for 2008.
Mississippi Power requested an 18 cent per 1,000 KWH decrease for retail customers.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Since the filing of the ECO Plan evaluation on February&nbsp;1, 2008, the regulations addressing mercury
emissions were altered by a decision issued by the U.S. Court of Appeals for the D.C. Circuit in
State of New Jersey v. Environmental Protection Agency on February&nbsp;8, 2008. On April&nbsp;7, 2008,
Mississippi Power filed with the Mississippi PSC a supplemental ECO Plan evaluation in which the
projects included in the ECO Plan
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->89<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>


<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>MISSISSIPPI POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">evaluation on February&nbsp;1, 2008 being undertaken primarily for mercury control were removed. In
this supplemental ECO filing, Mississippi Power changed the request to a 15 cent per 1,000 KWH
decrease for retail residential customers. Hearings with the Mississippi PSC are expected to be
held in May&nbsp;2008. The outcome of the 2008 supplemental ECO Plan filing cannot now be determined.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Performance Evaluation Plan</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See Note&nbsp;3 to the financial statements of Mississippi Power under &#147;Retail Regulatory Matters&nbsp;&#150;
Performance Evaluation Plan&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for information on Mississippi Power&#146;s base
rates. In a May&nbsp;2004 order establishing Mississippi Power&#146;s forward-looking rate schedule PEP, the
Mississippi PSC ordered that the Mississippi Public Utility Staff and Mississippi Power review the
operations of the PEP in 2007. By mutual agreement, this review was deferred and will occur in
2008.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In December&nbsp;2007, Mississippi Power submitted its annual PEP filing for 2008, which resulted in a
rate increase of 1.983% or $15.5&nbsp;million annually, effective January&nbsp;2008. In March&nbsp;2008,
Mississippi Power submitted its annual PEP lookback filing for 2007, which recommended no surcharge
or refund. The filing is under review by the Mississippi Public Utility Staff; therefore, the
ultimate outcome of this filing cannot now be determined.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Fuel Cost Recovery</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;PSC Matters &#150; Fuel Cost
Recovery&#148; of Mississippi Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for information regarding Mississippi
Power&#146;s fuel cost recovery. At March&nbsp;31, 2008, the under recovered balance of fuel recorded in
Mississippi Power&#146;s Condensed Balance Sheets herein was $26.2&nbsp;million compared to $40.5&nbsp;million at
December&nbsp;31, 2007. Mississippi Power&#146;s operating revenues are adjusted for differences in actual
recoverable fuel cost and amounts billed in accordance with the currently approved cost recovery
rate. Accordingly, changes to the billing factor will have no significant effect on Mississippi
Power&#146;s revenues or net income but will affect cash flow.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Mississippi Base Load Construction Legislation</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In the 2008 regular session of the Mississippi legislature, a bill was introduced to enhance the
Mississippi PSC&#146;s authority to facilitate development and construction of base load generation
in the State of Mississippi. The bill, passed by the legislature on April&nbsp;16, 2008 and awaiting
approval by the Governor, authorizes, but does not require, the Mississippi PSC to include in
retail base rates, prior to and during construction, all or a portion of the prudently incurred
pre-construction and construction costs incurred by a utility in constructing a base load
electric generating plant. The bill also provides for periodic prudence reviews by the
Mississippi PSC and prohibits the cancellation of any such generating plant without the approval
of the Mississippi PSC. In the event of cancellation of the construction of the plant without
approval of the Mississippi PSC, the bill authorizes the Mississippi PSC to make a public
interest determination as to whether and to what extent the utility will be afforded rate
recovery for costs incurred in connection with such cancelled generating plant.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->90<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>


<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>MISSISSIPPI POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Kemper County Integrated Coal Gasification Combined Cycle</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">As part of the evaluation and screening of alternatives to meet its future generation needs,
Mississippi Power is considering the construction of an advanced coal gasification facility to be
located in Kemper County, Mississippi, that would use locally mined lignite coal. The plant would
use an air-blown IGCC technology that generates power from low-rank coals and coals with high
moisture or high ash content. These coals, which include lignite, make up approximately half the
proven United States and worldwide coal reserves. The feasibility assessment of the project is
currently underway. Mississippi Power filed an application in June&nbsp;2006 with the DOE for certain
tax credits available to projects using clean coal technologies under the Energy Policy Act of
2005. The DOE subsequently certified the project and in November&nbsp;2006, the IRS allocated IRC
Section&nbsp;48A tax credits of $133&nbsp;million to Mississippi Power. The utilization of these credits is
dependent upon meeting the certification requirements for the project, including an in-service date
no later than November&nbsp;2013. On February&nbsp;14, 2008, Mississippi Power also requested that the DOE
transfer the remaining funds previously granted to another Southern Company project that would have
been located in Orlando, Florida. The Orlando project was cancelled in 2007.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In December&nbsp;2006, the Mississippi PSC approved Mississippi Power&#146;s request for accounting treatment
of the costs associated with Mississippi Power&#146;s generation resource planning, evaluation, and
screening activities. The Mississippi PSC gave Mississippi Power the authority to create and
recognize a regulatory asset for such costs. In December&nbsp;2007, Mississippi Power reported to the
Mississippi PSC an updated estimate and received an order directing Mississippi Power to continue
charging all costs associated with the generation capacity assessment to the regulatory asset. At
March&nbsp;31, 2008, Mississippi Power had spent $25.3&nbsp;million, of which $2.7&nbsp;million related to land
purchases capitalized. The retail portion of $16.4&nbsp;million was deferred in other regulatory assets
and the wholesale portion of $6.2&nbsp;million was expensed. The retail portion of these costs will be
charged to and remain as a regulatory asset until the Mississippi PSC determines the prudence and
ultimate recovery of such costs, which decision is expected by January&nbsp;2009. The balance of such
regulatory asset is included in Mississippi Power&#146;s rate base for retail ratemaking purposes.
Approval by various regulatory agencies, including the Mississippi PSC, will also be required if
the project proceeds. The Mississippi PSC, in its discretion, may exercise its additional rate
authority granted to the Mississippi PSC in the Mississippi base load construction legislation if
such legislation is signed by the Governor and if the project proceeds. See &#147;Mississippi Base Load
Construction Legislation&#148; herein for additional information.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The final outcome of this matter cannot now be determined.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Income Tax Matters</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><I>Bonus Depreciation</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">On February&nbsp;13, 2008, President Bush signed the Economic Stimulus Act of 2008 (Stimulus Act) into
law. The Stimulus Act includes a provision that allows 50% bonus depreciation for certain property
acquired in 2008 and placed in service in 2008 or, in certain limited cases, 2009. Mississippi
Power is currently assessing the financial implications of the Stimulus Act and estimates the cash
flow reduction to tax payments for 2008 to be between $6&nbsp;million and $9&nbsp;million.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->91<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>MISSISSIPPI POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Other Matters</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Mississippi Power is involved in various other matters being litigated and regulatory matters that
could affect future earnings. In addition, Mississippi Power is subject to certain claims and
legal actions arising in the ordinary course of business. Mississippi Power&#146;s business activities
are subject to extensive governmental regulation related to public health and the environment.
Litigation over environmental issues and claims of various types, including property damage,
personal injury, common law nuisance, and citizen enforcement of environmental requirements such as
opacity and air and water quality standards, has increased generally throughout the United States.
In particular, personal injury claims for damages caused by alleged exposure to hazardous materials
have become more frequent. The ultimate outcome of such pending or potential litigation against
Mississippi Power cannot be predicted at this time; however, for current proceedings not
specifically reported herein or in Note 3 to the financial statements of Mississippi Power in Item
8 of the Form 10-K, management does not anticipate that the liabilities, if any, arising from such
current proceedings would have a material adverse effect on Mississippi Power&#146;s financial
statements.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See the Notes to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for discussion of various other
contingencies, regulatory matters, and other matters being litigated which may affect future
earnings potential.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>ACCOUNTING POLICIES</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>Application of Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Mississippi Power prepares its financial statements in accordance with accounting principles
generally accepted in the United States. Significant accounting policies are described in Note 1
to the financial statements of Mississippi Power in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K. In the application of
these policies, certain estimates are made that may have a material impact on Mississippi Power&#146;s
results of operations and related disclosures. Different assumptions and measurements could
produce estimates that are significantly different from those recorded in the financial statements.
See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; ACCOUNTING POLICIES &#150; &#147;Application of Critical
Accounting Policies and Estimates&#148; of Mississippi Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for a complete
discussion of Mississippi Power&#146;s critical accounting policies and estimates related to Electric
Utility Regulation, Contingent Obligations, Unbilled Revenues, and Plant Daniel Operating Lease.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>Overview</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Mississippi Power&#146;s financial condition remained stable at March&nbsp;31, 2008. Net cash used for
operating activities totaled $14.5&nbsp;million for the first quarter 2008, compared to $6.6&nbsp;million net
cash provided from operating activities for the first quarter 2007. The $21.1&nbsp;million increase in
net cash used for operating activities in the first quarter 2008 was primarily due to an increase
in prepaid income taxes in the amount of $14.0&nbsp;million primarily as a result of the receipt of a
tax refund in the first quarter 2007. Also, contributing to the increase in the
use of funds was an increase in materials and supplies of $12.2&nbsp;million primarily due to 2008
project delays. These increases in cash used for operating activities were partially offset by
increases in fuel inventory of $6.8&nbsp;million. The change in net cash used for investing activities
was not material. Net cash provided from financing activities totaled $65.7&nbsp;million for the first
quarter 2008, compared to $18.3&nbsp;million for the first quarter 2007. The $47.4&nbsp;million increase in
net cash provided from financing activities was primarily due to the $80&nbsp;million long-term bank
loan made to Mississippi Power on March&nbsp;5, 2008, offset by short-term borrowings in the first
quarter 2007 of approximately $35&nbsp;million.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->92<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>MISSISSIPPI POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Significant balance sheet changes for the first three months of 2008 include an increase in cash
and cash equivalents of $27.0&nbsp;million as well as an increase in long-term debt of $80.0&nbsp;million due
to a long-term bank loan made to Mississippi Power on March&nbsp;5, 2008 which was offset by a $40.0
million reclassification of a senior note that will mature in March&nbsp;2009. Receivables from
affiliated companies also increased by $23.0&nbsp;million primarily due to an increase in sales to
affiliate companies in accordance with the IIC. There is also an increase in current assets from
risk management activities of $23.4&nbsp;million primarily due to mark to market gains on energy-related
derivative positions.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Capital Requirements and Contractual Obligations</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY &#150; &#147;Capital
Requirements and Contractual Obligations&#148; of Mississippi Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for a
description of Mississippi Power&#146;s capital requirements for its construction program, lease
obligations, purchase commitments, derivative obligations, preferred stock dividends, and trust
funding requirements. Approximately $41&nbsp;million will be required through March&nbsp;31, 2009 for
maturities of long-term debt.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Sources of Capital</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Mississippi Power plans to obtain the funds required for construction and other purposes from
sources similar to those utilized in the past. Mississippi Power has primarily utilized funds from
operating cash flows, short-term debt, external security offerings, and equity contributions from
Southern Company. However, the amount, type, and timing of any future financings, if needed, will
depend upon regulatory approval, prevailing market conditions, and other factors. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S
DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY &#150; &#147;Sources of Capital&#148; of Mississippi
Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for additional information.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Mississippi Power&#146;s current liabilities frequently exceed current assets because of the continued
use of short-term debt as a funding source to meet scheduled maturities of long-term debt as well
as cash needs which can fluctuate significantly due to the seasonality of the business. To meet
short-term cash needs and contingencies, Mississippi Power had at March&nbsp;31, 2008 approximately $32
million of cash and cash equivalents and $181&nbsp;million of unused committed credit arrangements with
banks. All of these facilities expire in 2008. Approximately $39&nbsp;million of these credit
arrangements contain provisions allowing two-year term loans executable at expiration and $15
million contain provisions allowing one-year term loans executable at expiration. Mississippi
Power expects to renew its credit facilities, as needed, prior to expiration. See Note 6 to the
financial statements of Mississippi Power under &#147;Bank Credit Arrangements&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form
10-K for additional information. The credit arrangements provide liquidity support to Mississippi
Power&#146;s obligations with respect to variable rate pollution control bonds and commercial paper.
Mississippi Power may also meet short-term cash needs through a Southern Company subsidiary
organized to issue and sell commercial paper and extendible commercial notes at the request and for
the benefit of Mississippi Power and other Southern Company subsidiaries. At March&nbsp;31, 2008,
Mississippi Power had $11.8&nbsp;million of commercial paper outstanding. Management believes that the
need for working capital can be adequately met by utilizing commercial paper programs and lines of
credit without maintaining large cash balances.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->93<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>


<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>MISSISSIPPI POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Off-Balance Sheet Financing Arrangements</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY &#150; &#147;Off-Balance Sheet
Financing Arrangements&#148; of Mississippi Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 7 to the financial statements of
Mississippi Power under &#147;Operating Leases&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for information related to
Mississippi Power&#146;s lease of a combined cycle generating facility at Plant Daniel.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Credit Rating Risk</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Mississippi Power does not have any credit arrangements that would require material changes in
payment schedules or terminations as a result of a credit rating downgrade. There are certain
contracts that could require collateral, but not accelerated payment, in the event of a credit
rating change to below BBB- or Baa3. These contracts are primarily for electricity sales and coal
purchases. At March&nbsp;31, 2008, the maximum potential collateral requirements at a rating below BBB-
or Baa3 were approximately $8&nbsp;million. Generally, collateral may be provided by a Southern Company
guaranty, letter of credit, or cash.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Mississippi Power, along with all members of the Power Pool, is party to certain energy-related
derivative agreements that could require collateral and/or accelerated payment in the event of a
credit rating change to below investment grade for Alabama Power and/or Georgia Power. These
agreements are primarily for natural gas and power price risk management activities. At March&nbsp;31,
2008, Mississippi Power&#146;s total exposure to these types of agreements was approximately $47
million.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Market Price Risk</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Mississippi Power&#146;s market risk exposures relative to interest rate changes have not changed
materially compared with the December&nbsp;31, 2007 reporting period. In addition, Mississippi Power is
not aware of any facts or circumstances that would significantly affect such exposures in the near
term.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Due to cost-based rate regulation, Mississippi Power has limited exposure to market volatility in
interest rates, commodity fuel prices, and prices of electricity. To mitigate residual risks
relative to movements in electricity prices, Mississippi Power enters into physical fixed-price
contracts for the purchase and sale of electricity through the wholesale electricity market.
Mississippi Power has also implemented retail fuel-hedging programs at the instruction of the
Mississippi PSC and wholesale fuel-hedging programs under agreements with wholesale customers.
</DIV>

follows:

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Gains and losses on energy-related derivative contracts related to Mississippi Power&#146;s fuel hedging
program are initially recorded as regulatory liabilities and assets, respectively, and then are
included in fuel expense as they are recovered through the energy cost management clause. Certain
other gains and losses on energy-related derivatives, designated as hedges, are initially deferred
in other comprehensive income before being recognized in income in the same period as the hedged
transaction. Gains and losses on energy-related derivative contracts that are not designated as
hedges are recognized in the statements of income as incurred.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">As part of the adoption of SFAS No.&nbsp;157 to increase consistency and comparability in fair value
measurements and related disclosures, the table above now uses the three-tier fair value hierarchy,
as discussed in Note (C)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein, as opposed to the previously
used descriptions &#147;actively quoted,&#148; &#147;external sources,&#148; and &#147;models and other methods.&#148; The
three-tier fair value hierarchy focuses on the fair value of the contract itself, whereas the
previous descriptions focused on the source of the inputs. Because Mississippi Power uses
over-the-counter contracts that are not exchange traded but are fair valued using prices which are
actively quoted, the valuations of those contracts now appear in Level 2; previously they were
shown as &#147;actively quoted.&#148;
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">For additional information, see MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND
LIQUIDITY &#150; &#147;Market Price Risk&#148; of Mississippi Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Notes 1 and 6 to the financial
statements of Mississippi Power under &#147;Financial Instruments&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K and Note
(F)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein.
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>MISSISSIPPI POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Financing Activities</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">On March&nbsp;5, 2008, Mississippi Power entered into an $80.0&nbsp;million long-term bank loan that bears
interest based on one-month LIBOR. Proceeds were used to repay a portion of Mississippi Power&#146;s
short-term indebtedness and for other corporate purposes, including Mississippi Power&#146;s continuous
construction activities.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Also in 2008, Mississippi Power converted its entire $42.6&nbsp;million of obligations related to
auction rate tax-exempt securities from an auction rate mode to a fixed rate mode.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In addition to any financings that may be necessary to meet capital requirements, contractual
obligations, and storm restoration costs, Mississippi Power plans to continue, when economically
feasible, a program to retire higher-cost securities and replace these obligations with lower-cost
capital if market conditions permit.
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->96<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>



<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="left">
<A name="137"></A>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 14pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>SOUTHERN

<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left">
<A name="140"></A>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>SOUTHERN POWER COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left">
<A name="140"></A>
</DIV>
<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED STATEMENTS OF CASH FLOWS (UNAUDITED)</DIV>


<DIV align="center">
<TABLE style="font-size: 10pt" cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%">
<!-- Begin Table Head -->
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD width="76%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>

</DIV>


<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>SOUTHERN POWER COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left">
<A name="141"></A>
</DIV>
<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED BALANCE SHEETS (UNAUDITED)</DIV>


<DIV align="center">
<TABLE style="font-size: 10pt" cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%">
<!-- Begin Table Head -->
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD width="76%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size: 8pt" valign="bottom">
