<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="left">
<A name="142"></A>
</DIV>



<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>SOUTHERN POWER COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left">
<A name="142"></A>
</DIV>
<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF</DIV>


<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</DIV>



<DIV align="Center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">FIRST QUARTER 2008 vs. FIRST QUARTER 2007

</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>OVERVIEW</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Southern Power and its wholly-owned subsidiaries construct, acquire, own, and manage generation
assets and sell electricity at market-based prices in the southeastern wholesale market. Southern
Power continues to execute its regional strategy through a combination of acquiring and
constructing new power plants and by entering into PPAs with investor owned utilities, independent
power producers, municipalities, and electric cooperatives.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">To evaluate operating results and to ensure Southern Power&#146;s ability to meet its contractual
commitments to customers, Southern Power focuses on several key performance indicators. These
indicators include peak season equivalent forced outage rate (EFOR), and net income. EFOR defines
the hours during peak demand times when Southern Power&#146;s generating units are not available due to
forced outages (the lower the better). For additional information on these indicators, see
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; OVERVIEW &#150; &#147;Key Performance Indicators&#148; of Southern Power in
Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B><I>Net Income</I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center">
<TABLE style="font-size: 10pt" cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%">
<!-- Begin Table Head -->
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD width="47%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="47%">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size: 8pt" valign="bottom">
    <TD nowrap align="center" colspan="3" style="border-bottom: 1px solid #000000">First Quarter 2008 vs. First Quarter 2007</TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size: 8pt" valign="bottom">
    <TD nowrap align="center"><I>(change in millions)</I></TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD nowrap align="center"><I>% change</I></TD>
</TR>

<!-- End Table Head -->
<!-- Begin Table Body -->
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD align="center" valign="top"><DIV style="margin-left:15px; text-indent:-15px">$(3.0)
</DIV></TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="center" valign="top">(9.6)</TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size: 1px">
    <TD colspan="3" valign="top" align="left" style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">&nbsp; &nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<!-- End Table Body -->
</TABLE>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Southern Power&#146;s net income for the first quarter 2008 was $29.0&nbsp;million compared to $32.0&nbsp;million
for the corresponding period of 2007. This decrease was primarily due to mark to market losses on
forward sales of uncontracted generating capacity, transmission service and tariff penalties
incurred during the first quarter 2008, and increased depreciation expense associated with the
implementation of a new depreciation study. These unfavorable impacts were partially offset by a
gain on the sale of an undeveloped tract of land and the receipt of a fee for participating in an
asset auction during the first quarter 2008.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B><I>Wholesale
Revenues &#150; Affiliates and Wholesale Revenues &#150; Non-Affiliates</I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center">
<TABLE style="font-size: 10pt" cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%">
<!-- Begin Table Head -->
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD width="47%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="47%">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size: 8pt" valign="bottom">
    <TD nowrap align="center" colspan="3" style="border-bottom: 1px solid #000000">First Quarter 2008 vs. First Quarter 2007</TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size: 8pt" valign="bottom">
    <TD nowrap align="center"><I>(change in millions)</I></TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD nowrap align="center"><I>% change</I></TD>
</TR>

<!-- End Table Head -->
<!-- Begin Table Body -->
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD align="center" valign="top">$23.3
</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="center" valign="top">12.2</TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size: 1px">
    <TD colspan="3" valign="top" align="left" style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">&nbsp; &nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<!-- End Table Body -->
</TABLE>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Wholesale revenues for the first quarter 2008 were $214.0&nbsp;million compared to $190.6&nbsp;million for
the corresponding period of 2007. Wholesale energy sales to non-affiliates will vary depending on
the energy demand of those customers and their generation capacity, as well as the market cost of
available energy compared to the cost of Southern Power. Energy sales to affiliated companies
within the Southern Company system will vary depending on demand and the availability and cost of
generating resources at each company. Sales to affiliate companies that are not covered by PPAs
are made in accordance with the IIC, as approved by the FERC. Wholesale revenues from
non-affiliates decreased $0.6&nbsp;million during the period, primarily due to two offsetting factors.
The first is a mark to market loss of $28.3&nbsp;million on forward sales of uncontracted generating
capacity arising from an increase in forward market prices. Secondly, offsetting this loss were
increases of $27.7&nbsp;million in short-term market energy revenues,
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->102<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>






<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>SOUTHERN POWER COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">increased energy revenues due to
higher natural gas prices, and revenues from Plant Oleander Unit 5. Wholesale revenues from
affiliates increased $24.0
million during the period, primarily due to increased demand under existing PPAs with affiliates
due to favorable weather within the Southern Company service territory.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;Power Sales Agreements&#148; of
Southern Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for additional information.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B><I>Fuel and Purchased Power Expenses</I></B>

</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In the first quarter 2008, total fuel and purchased power expenses were $103.3&nbsp;million compared to
$69.7&nbsp;million for the corresponding period in 2007. These increases were primarily due to
increased generation and purchases of $19&nbsp;million in order to meet the higher energy sales as well
as higher fuel and purchased power costs of $28.6&nbsp;million due to an increase in the average cost of
fuel and purchased power. Mark to market gains of $13.9&nbsp;million on forward natural gas derivatives
and forward power purchases offset a portion of these increases.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In the first quarter 2008, other operations and maintenance expenses were $35.0&nbsp;million compared to
$26.2&nbsp;million in the same period in 2007. This increase was primarily due to transmission service
and tariff penalties of $3.6&nbsp;million, timing of plant maintenance activities of $3.1&nbsp;million, and
general and administrative expenses of $2.1&nbsp;million due to implementation of the FERC separation
order.
</DIV>

a decrease of $1.5&nbsp;million due to the federal production activities deduction.

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The results of operations discussed above are not necessarily indicative of Southern Power&#146;s future
earnings potential. A number of factors affect the opportunities, challenges, and risks of
Southern Power&#146;s competitive wholesale energy business. These factors include the ability to
achieve sales growth while containing costs. Another major factor is federal regulatory policy,
which may impact Southern Power&#146;s level of participation in this market. The level of future
earnings depends on numerous factors, including regulatory matters (such as those related to
affiliate contracts), sales, creditworthiness of customers, total generating capacity available in
the Southeast, and the successful remarketing of capacity as current contracts expire. For
additional information relating to these issues, see RISK FACTORS in Item&nbsp;1A and MANAGEMENT&#146;S
DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL of Southern Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Construction Projects</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><I>Plant Franklin Unit 3</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Southern Power restarted construction activities on Plant Franklin Unit 3 in 2006, with an expected
completion date in June&nbsp;2008. The total cost is expected to be approximately $304.4&nbsp;million, of
which $294.2&nbsp;million had been spent as of March&nbsp;31, 2008. The expected capacity of this unit is
621 MW and will be used to provide annual capacity for a PPA with Constellation Energy Group, Inc.
from 2009 through 2015.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Environmental Matters</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;Environmental Matters&#148; of
Southern Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for information on the
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->104<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>


<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>SOUTHERN POWER COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">development by federal and state environmental regulatory agencies of additional control strategies
for emission of air pollution from industrial sources, including electric generating facilities.
Compliance with possible additional federal or state legislation or regulations related to global
climate change, air quality, or other environmental and health concerns could also affect earnings.
While Southern Power&#146;s PPAs generally contain provisions that permit charging the counterparty
with some of the new costs incurred as a result of changes in environmental laws and regulations,
the full impact of any such regulatory or legislative changes cannot be determined at this time.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Carbon Dioxide Litigation</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">On February&nbsp;26, 2008, the Native Village of Kivalina and the City of Kivalina filed a suit in the
U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against several electric utilities
(including Southern Company), several oil companies, and a coal company. The plaintiffs are the
governing bodies of an Inupiat village in Alaska. The plaintiffs contend that the village is being
destroyed by erosion allegedly caused by global warming that the plaintiffs attribute to emissions
of greenhouse gases by the defendants. The plaintiffs assert claims for public and private
nuisance and contend that the defendants have acted in concert and are therefore jointly and
severally liable for the plaintiffs&#146; damages. The suit seeks damages for lost property values and
for the cost of relocating the village, which cost is alleged to be $95&nbsp;million to $400&nbsp;million.
Southern Company believes that these claims are without merit and notes that the complaint cites no
statutory or regulatory basis for the claims. The ultimate outcome of this matter cannot be
determined at this time.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Other Matters</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Southern Power is involved in various other matters being litigated and regulatory matters that
could affect future earnings. In addition, Southern Power is subject to certain claims and legal
actions arising in the ordinary course of business. Southern Power&#146;s business activities are
subject to extensive governmental regulation related to public health and the environment.
Litigation over environmental issues and claims of various types, including property damage,
personal injury, common law nuisance, and citizen enforcement of environmental requirements such as
opacity and air and water quality standards, has increased generally throughout the United States.
In particular, personal injury claims for damages caused by alleged exposure to hazardous materials
have become more frequent. The ultimate outcome of such potential litigation against Southern Power
and its subsidiaries cannot be predicted at this time; however, for current proceedings not
specifically reported herein or in Note 3 to the financial statements Southern Power in Item&nbsp;8 of
the Form 10-K, management does not anticipate that the liabilities, if any, arising from any such
proceedings would have a material adverse effect on Southern Power&#146;s financial statements.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See Note (B)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for discussion of various other
contingencies, regulatory matters, and other matters being litigated which may affect future
earnings potential.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>ACCOUNTING POLICIES</B>

principles generally accepted in the United States. Significant accounting policies are described
in Note 1 to the financial statements of Southern Power in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K. In the
application of these policies, certain estimates are made that may have a material impact on
Southern Power&#146;s results of operations and related disclosures. Different assumptions and
measurements could produce estimates that are
</DIV>

</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>New Accounting Standards</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><I>Business Combinations</I>

</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In December&nbsp;2007, the FASB issued FASB Statement No.&nbsp;141 (revised 2007), &#147;Business Combinations&#148;
(SFAS No.&nbsp;141R). SFAS No.&nbsp;141R, when adopted, will significantly change the accounting for
business combinations, specifically the accounting for contingent consideration, contingencies,
acquisition costs, and restructuring costs. Southern Power plans to adopt SFAS No.&nbsp;141R on January
1, 2009. It is likely that the adoption of SFAS No.&nbsp;141R will have a significant impact on the
accounting for any business combinations completed by Southern Power after January&nbsp;1, 2009.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In December&nbsp;2007, the FASB issued FASB Statement No.&nbsp;160, &#147;Non-controlling Interests in
Consolidated Financial Statements&#148; (SFAS No.&nbsp;160). SFAS No.&nbsp;160 amends Accounting Research Bulletin
No.&nbsp;51, &#147;Consolidated Financial Statements&#148; to establish accounting and reporting standards for the
non-controlling (minority)&nbsp;interest in a subsidiary and for the deconsolidation of a subsidiary.
It clarifies that a non-controlling interest in a subsidiary should be reported as equity in the
consolidated financial statements and establishes a single method of accounting for changes in a
parent&#146;s ownership interest in a subsidiary that do not result in deconsolidation. Southern Power
plans to adopt SFAS No.&nbsp;160 on January&nbsp;1, 2009 and is currently assessing its impact, if any.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>Overview</B>

</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Southern Power&#146;s financial condition remained stable at March&nbsp;31, 2008. Net cash provided from
operating activities totaled $29.9&nbsp;million for the first quarter 2008, compared to $45.7&nbsp;million
for the first quarter 2007. The $15.8&nbsp;million decrease in cash provided from operating activities
in the first quarter 2008 is primarily due to costs incurred on the construction of the combined
cycle unit for the Orlando Utilities Commission. Net cash used for investing activities totaled
$20.9&nbsp;million for the first quarter 2008, compared to $40.7&nbsp;million for the first quarter 2007.
This decrease is primarily due to a reduction in capital expenditures as Plant Oleander Unit 5 was
completed in December&nbsp;2007 and the gasifier portion of the IGCC project was terminated in November
2007. Net cash used for financing activities totaled $9.0&nbsp;million for the first quarter 2008,
compared to $1.1&nbsp;million for the first quarter 2007. This increase is primarily due to a reduction
of outstanding commercial paper and an increase in dividends paid to Southern Company. Southern
Power paid dividends to Southern Company of $23.6&nbsp;million in the first quarter 2008.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Significant balance sheet changes for the first quarter 2008 include increases in assets and
liabilities for Southern Power&#146;s risk management activities due to increases in the forward market
prices for power and natural gas. Other asset changes include the completion of the sale of land
that was held for sale at December&nbsp;31, 2007. Other liability changes include a reduction in other
current liabilities due to
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->106<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>



<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>SOUTHERN POWER COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">payment of IGCC termination costs of $ 2.6&nbsp;million and a reduction of deferred capacity revenues
due to seasonality.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Capital Requirements and Contractual Obligations</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY &#150; &#147;Capital
Requirements and Contractual Obligations&#148; of Southern Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for a
description of Southern Power&#146;s capital requirements for its construction program, maturing debt,
interest, leases, derivative obligations, purchase commitments, and long-term service agreements.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Sources of Capital</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Southern Power may use operating cash flows, external funds, or equity capital from Southern
Company to finance any new projects, acquisitions, and ongoing capital requirements. Southern
Power expects to generate external funds from the issuance of unsecured senior debt and commercial
paper or utilization of credit arrangements from banks. However, the amount, type, and timing of
any financings, if needed, will depend upon regulatory approval, prevailing market conditions, and
other factors. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY &#150;
&#147;Sources of Capital&#148; of Southern Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for additional information.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Southern Power&#146;s current liabilities frequently exceed current assets due to the use of short-term
indebtedness as a funding source, as well as cash needs which can fluctuate significantly due to
the seasonality of the business. To meet liquidity and capital resource requirements, Southern
Power had at March&nbsp;31, 2008 approximately $400&nbsp;million in committed credit arrangements with banks
that expire in 2012. Borrowings of $50&nbsp;million under these arrangements were outstanding as of
March&nbsp;31, 2008. Proceeds from these credit arrangements may be used for working capital and
general corporate purposes as well as liquidity support for Southern Power&#146;s commercial paper
program.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Southern Power&#146;s commercial paper program is used to finance acquisition and construction costs
related to electric generating facilities and for general corporate purposes. At March&nbsp;31, 2008,
there was $13.5&nbsp;million of commercial paper outstanding.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Management believes that the need for working capital can be adequately met by utilizing commercial
paper programs and lines of credit without maintaining large cash balances.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Credit Rating Risk</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Southern Power does not have any credit arrangements that would require material changes in payment
schedules or terminations as a result of a credit rating downgrade. There are certain contracts
that could require collateral, but not accelerated payment, in the event of a credit rating change
to BBB and Baa2 or to BBB- or Baa3 or below. These contracts are primarily for physical
electricity purchases and sales. At March&nbsp;31, 2008, the maximum potential collateral requirements
at a BBB and Baa2 rating were approximately $9&nbsp;million and at a BBB- or Baa3 rating were
approximately $271&nbsp;million. At March&nbsp;31, 2008, the maximum potential collateral requirements at a
rating below BBB- or Baa3 were approximately $463&nbsp;million. Generally, collateral may be provided
by a Southern Company guaranty, letter of credit, or cash.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In addition, Southern Power is party to a PPA that could require collateral, but not accelerated
payment, in the event of a downgrade to Southern Power&#146;s credit rating to below BBB- or Baa3. The
amount of
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->107<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>


<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>SOUTHERN POWER COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">collateral required would depend upon actual losses, if any, resulting from a credit downgrade,
limited to
Southern Power&#146;s remaining obligations under the contract.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Southern Power, along with the other members of the Power Pool, is also party to certain agreements
that could require collateral and/or accelerated payment in the event of a credit rating change to
below investment grade for Alabama Power and/or Georgia Power. These agreements are primarily for
natural gas and power price risk management activities. At March&nbsp;31, 2008, Southern Power&#146;s total
exposure to these types of agreements was approximately $47&nbsp;million.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Market Price Risk</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Southern Power&#146;s market risk exposures relative to interest rate changes have not changed
materially compared with the December&nbsp;31, 2007 reporting period. In addition, Southern Power is not
aware of any facts or circumstances that would significantly affect such exposures in the near
term.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Southern Power is exposed to market risks, including changes in interest rates, certain
energy-related commodity prices, and, occasionally, currency exchange rates. To manage the
volatility attributable to these exposures, Southern Power nets the exposures to take advantage of
natural offsets and enters into various derivative transactions for the remaining exposures
pursuant to Southern Power&#146;s policies in areas such as counterparty exposure and hedging practices.
Southern Power&#146;s policy is that derivatives are to be used primarily for hedging purposes.
Derivative positions are monitored using techniques that include market valuation and sensitivity
analysis.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Because energy from Southern Power&#146;s facilities is primarily sold under long-term PPAs with tolling
agreements and provisions shifting substantially all of the responsibility for fuel cost to the
counterparties, Southern Power&#146;s exposure to market volatility in commodity fuel prices and prices
of electricity is generally limited. However, during 2008, Southern Power is exposed to market
volatility in energy-related commodity prices as a result of sales of uncontracted generating
capacity.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The change in fair value of energy-related derivative contracts and valuations at March&nbsp;31, 2008
were as follows:
</DIV>
<DIV align="center">

<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>



<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">






<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>SOUTHERN POWER COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Gains and losses on energy-related derivatives used by Southern Power to hedge anticipated
purchases and sales are initially deferred in other comprehensive income before being recognized in
income in the same period as the hedged transaction. Gains and losses on energy-related derivative
contracts that are not designated or fail to qualify as hedges are recognized in the statements of
income as incurred.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The fair value gain/(loss) of energy-related derivative contracts outstanding at March&nbsp;31, 2008 was
reflected in the financial statements as follows:
</DIV>
<DIV align="center">
<TABLE style="font-size: 10pt" cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%">
<!-- Begin Table Head -->
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD width="88%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="0%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="0%">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size: 8pt" valign="bottom">
    <TD nowrap align="left" style="border-bottom: 1px solid #000000">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD style="border-bottom: 1px solid #000000">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD nowrap align="center" colspan="3" style="border-bottom: 1px solid #000000"><B>Amounts</B></TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size: 8pt" valign="bottom">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD colspan="3" nowrap align="left"><I>(in millions)</I></TD>
</TR>

<!-- End Table Head -->
<!-- Begin Table Body -->
<TR valign="bottom" style="background: #cceeff">
    <TD><DIV style="margin-left:15px; text-indent:-15px">Accumulated other comprehensive income</DIV></TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD nowrap align="right">$</TD>
    <TD align="right">(7.5</TD>
    <TD nowrap>)</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD><DIV style="margin-left:15px; text-indent:-15px">Net income</DIV></TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD nowrap align="right">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="right">(11.1</TD>
    <TD nowrap>)</TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size: 1px">
    <TD colspan="5" align="left" style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD nowrap align="right">$</TD>
    <TD align="right">(18.6</TD>
    <TD nowrap>)</TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size: 1px">

</TR>
<!-- End Table Body -->
</TABLE>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Unrealized pre-tax gains and losses recognized in income for the three months ended March&nbsp;31, 2008
for energy-related derivative contracts that are not hedges were $14.4&nbsp;million and will continue to
be marked to market until the settlement date. These amounts were immaterial for the three months
ended March&nbsp;31, 2007.
</DIV>

in which they fall at March&nbsp;31, 2008 are as follows:

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">As part of the adoption of SFAS No.&nbsp;157 to increase consistency and comparability in fair value
measurements and related disclosures, the table above now uses the three-tier fair value hierarchy,
as discussed in Note (C)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein, as opposed to the previously
used descriptions &#147;actively quoted,&#148; &#147;external sources,&#148; and &#147;models and other methods.&#148; The
three-tier fair value hierarchy focuses on the fair value of the contract itself, whereas the
previous descriptions focused on the source of the inputs. Because Southern Power uses
over-the-counter contracts that are not exchange traded but are fair valued using prices which are
actively quoted, the valuations of those contracts now appear in Level 2; previously they were
shown as &#147;actively quoted.&#148;
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">For additional information, see MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND
LIQUIDITY &#150; &#147;Market Price Risk&#148; of Southern Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Notes 1 and 6 to the financial
statements of Southern Power under &#147;Financial Instruments&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K and Note (F)
to the Condensed Financial Statements herein.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Financing Activities</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Southern Power did not issue or redeem any long-term securities during the three months ended March
31, 2008.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>NOTES TO THE CONDENSED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS: (Continued)</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>THE SOUTHERN COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES<BR>
ALABAMA POWER COMPANY<BR>
GEORGIA POWER COMPANY<BR>
GULF POWER COMPANY<BR>
MISSISSIPPI POWER COMPANY<BR>
SOUTHERN POWER COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>NOTES TO THE CONDENSED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS:</B>
</DIV>


<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt">
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left">(A)</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>INTRODUCTION</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>The condensed quarterly financial statements of the registrants included herein have been
prepared by each registrant, without audit, pursuant to the rules and regulations of the
SEC. The Condensed Balance Sheets as of December&nbsp;31, 2007 have been derived from the
audited financial statements of each registrant. In the opinion of each registrant&#146;s
management, the information regarding such registrant furnished herein reflects all
adjustments necessary to present fairly the results of operations for the periods ended
March&nbsp;31, 2008 and 2007. Certain information and footnote disclosures normally included in
annual financial statements prepared in accordance with accounting principles generally
accepted in the United States have been condensed or omitted pursuant to such rules and
regulations, although each registrant believes that the disclosures regarding such
registrant are adequate to make the information presented not misleading. Disclosures which
would substantially duplicate the disclosures in the latest Form 10-K and details which have
not changed significantly in amount or composition since the filing of the Form 10-K are
generally omitted from this Quarterly Report on Form 10-Q. Therefore, these Condensed
Financial Statements should be read in conjunction with the financial statements and the
notes thereto included in the Form 10-K. Due to the seasonal variations in the demand for
energy, operating results for the periods presented do not necessarily indicate operating
results for the entire year.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Certain prior period amounts have been reclassified to conform to current period
presentation. Where applicable, each company&#146;s statement of income for the first quarter
2007 was modified to report &#147;Interest expense to affiliate trusts&#148; together with &#147;Interest
expense, net of amounts capitalized.&#148; Southern Company&#146;s statement of cash flows for the
prior period was modified within the operating activities section to present separate line
items for &#147;Derivative fair value adjustments&#148; and &#147;Deferred revenues&#148; previously included in
&#147;Other, net.&#148; Within the investing activities section, &#147;Proceeds from property sales&#148; was
combined into &#147;Other.&#148;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Alabama Power&#146;s statement of cash flows for the first quarter 2007 was modified within the
operating activities section to combine &#147;Deferred expenses &#150; affiliates&#148; into &#147;Other, net.&#148;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Georgia Power&#146;s statement of cash flows for the prior period was modified within the
operating activities section to present a separate line item for &#147;Deferred revenues&#148;
previously included in &#147;Other, net.&#148; Additionally, the line items &#147;Stock option expense&#148;
and &#147;Tax benefit of stock options&#148; were combined into &#147;Other, net&#148; and &#147;Material and
supplies&#148; was combined into &#147;Other current assets.&#148; In the financing activities section,
&#147;Gross excess tax benefit of stock options&#148; was combined into &#147;Other.&#148;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Gulf Power modified its statement of income for the three months ended March&nbsp;31, 2007 to
report a separate line item for &#147;Allowance for funds used during construction&#148; previously
included in &#147;Other income and expense, net.&#148; In conjunction with such modification, Gulf
Power modified its statement of cash flows within the operating activities section to
present a separate line item for &#147;Allowance for equity funds used during construction&#148;
previously included in &#147;Other, net.&#148;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->111<!-- /Folio -->

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
