    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left"><B>&nbsp;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%"><B>&nbsp;</B></TD>
    <TD><B>General Litigation Matters</B></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Each registrant is subject to certain claims and legal actions arising in the ordinary
course of business. In addition, each registrant&#146;s business activities are subject to
extensive governmental regulation related to public health and the environment. Litigation
over environmental issues and claims of various types, including property damage, personal
injury, common law nuisance, and citizen enforcement of environmental requirements such as
opacity and air and water quality standards, has increased generally throughout the United
States. In particular, personal injury claims for damages caused by alleged exposure to
hazardous materials have become more frequent. The ultimate outcome of such pending or
potential litigation against the registrants and any of their subsidiaries cannot be
predicted at this time; however, for current proceedings not specifically reported herein or
in Note 3 to the financial statements of each registrant in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K,
management does not anticipate that the liabilities, if any, arising from such current
proceedings would have a material adverse effect on such registrant&#146;s financial statements.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left"><B>&nbsp;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%"><B>&nbsp;</B></TD>
    <TD><B>Mirant Matters</B></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Mirant was an energy company with businesses that included independent power projects and
energy trading and risk management companies in the United States and selected other
countries. It was a wholly-owned subsidiary of Southern Company until its initial public
offering in October&nbsp;2000. In April&nbsp;2001, Southern Company completed a spin-off to its
shareholders of its remaining ownership, and Mirant became an independent corporate entity.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left"><B><I>&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD width="1%"><B><I>&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD><I>Mirant Bankruptcy</I></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>In July&nbsp;2003, Mirant and certain of its affiliates filed voluntary petitions for relief
under Chapter&nbsp;11 of the Bankruptcy Code in the U.S. Bankruptcy Court for the Northern
District of Texas. The Bankruptcy Court entered an order confirming Mirant&#146;s plan of
reorganization in December&nbsp;2005, and Mirant announced that this plan became effective in
January&nbsp;2006. As part of the plan, Mirant transferred substantially all of its assets and
its restructured debt to a new corporation that adopted the name Mirant Corporation
(Reorganized Mirant).</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->112<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>NOTES TO THE CONDENSED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS: (Continued)</B>
</DIV>



<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 6%">Southern Company has certain contingent liabilities associated with guarantees of
contractual commitments made by Mirant&#146;s subsidiaries discussed under &#147;Guarantees&#148; in Note 7
to the financial statements of Southern Company in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K and with various
lawsuits related to
Mirant discussed below. Also, Southern Company has joint and several liability with Mirant
regarding the joint consolidated federal income tax returns through 2001, as discussed in
Note 5 to the financial statements of Southern Company in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K. In
December&nbsp;2004, as a result of concluding an IRS audit for the tax years 2000 and 2001,
Southern Company paid approximately $39&nbsp;million in additional tax and interest related to
Mirant tax items and filed a claim in Mirant&#146;s bankruptcy case for that amount. Through
December&nbsp;2007, Southern Company received from the IRS approximately $36&nbsp;million in refunds
related to Mirant. Southern Company believes it has a right to recoup the $39&nbsp;million tax
payment owed by Mirant from such tax refunds. As a result, Southern Company intends to
retain the tax refunds and reduce its claim against Mirant for the payment of Mirant taxes
by the amount of such refunds. MC Asset Recovery, a special purpose subsidiary of
Reorganized Mirant, has objected to and sought to equitably subordinate the Southern Company
tax claim in its fraudulent transfer litigation against Southern Company. Southern Company
has reserved the approximately $3&nbsp;million amount remaining with respect to its Mirant tax
claim.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 6%">Under the terms of the separation agreements entered into in connection with the spin-off,
Mirant agreed to indemnify Southern Company for costs associated with these guarantees,
lawsuits, and additional IRS assessments. However, as a result of Mirant&#146;s bankruptcy,
Southern Company sought reimbursement as an unsecured creditor in Mirant&#146;s Chapter&nbsp;11
proceeding. As part of a complaint filed against Southern Company in June&nbsp;2005 and amended
thereafter, Mirant and The Official Committee of Unsecured Creditors of Mirant Corporation
(Unsecured Creditors&#146; Committee) objected to and sought equitable subordination of Southern
Company&#146;s claims, and Mirant moved to reject the separation agreements entered into in
connection with the spin-off. MC Asset Recovery has been substituted as plaintiff in the
complaint. If Southern Company&#146;s claims for indemnification with respect to these, or any
additional future payments, are allowed, then Mirant&#146;s indemnity obligations to Southern
Company would constitute unsecured claims against Mirant entitled to stock in Reorganized
Mirant. The final outcome of this matter cannot now be determined.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 6%"><I>MC Asset Recovery Litigation</I></DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 6%">In June&nbsp;2005, Mirant, as a debtor in possession, and the Unsecured Creditors&#146; Committee
filed a complaint against Southern Company in the U.S. Bankruptcy Court for the Northern
District of Texas, which was amended in July&nbsp;2005, February&nbsp;2006, May&nbsp;2006, and March&nbsp;2007.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 6%">In December&nbsp;2005, the Bankruptcy Court entered an order authorizing the transfer of this
proceeding, along with certain other actions, to MC Asset Recovery. Under that order,
Reorganized Mirant is obligated to fund up to $20&nbsp;million in professional fees in connection
with the lawsuits, as well as certain additional amounts. Any net recoveries from these
lawsuits will be distributed to, and shared equally by, certain unsecured creditors and the
original equity holders. In January&nbsp;2006, the U.S. District Court for the Northern District
of Texas substituted MC Asset Recovery as plaintiff.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 6%">The complaint, as amended in March&nbsp;2007, alleges that Southern Company caused Mirant to
engage in certain fraudulent transfers and to pay illegal dividends to Southern Company
prior to the spin-off. The alleged fraudulent transfers and illegal dividends include
without
limitation: (1)&nbsp;certain dividends from Mirant to Southern Company in the aggregate amount of
$668&nbsp;million, (2)&nbsp;the repayment of certain intercompany loans and accrued interest in an
aggregate amount of $1.035&nbsp;billion, and (3)&nbsp;the dividend distribution of one share of
Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock and its subsequent redemption in exchange for Mirant&#146;s 80% interest
in a holding company that owned SE Finance Capital Corporation and Southern Company Capital
Funding, Inc., which transfer plaintiff asserts is valued at over $200&nbsp;million. The
complaint also seeks to recharacterize certain advances from Southern Company
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->113<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>



<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>NOTES TO THE CONDENSED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS: (Continued)</B>
</DIV>



<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 6%">to Mirant for investments in energy facilities from debt to equity. The complaint further
alleges that Southern Company is liable to Mirant&#146;s creditors for the full amount of
Mirant&#146;s liability under an alter ego theory of recovery and that Southern Company breached
its fiduciary duties to Mirant and
its creditors, caused Mirant to breach its fiduciary duties to creditors, and aided and
abetted breaches of fiduciary duties by Mirant&#146;s directors and officers. The complaint also
seeks recoveries under the theories of restitution and unjust enrichment. In addition, the
complaint alleges a claim under the Federal Debt Collection Procedure Act (FDCPA)&nbsp;to void
certain transfers from Mirant to Southern Company. MC Asset Recovery claims to have
standing to assert violations of the FDCPA and to recover property on behalf of the Mirant
debtors&#146; estates. The complaint seeks monetary damages in excess of $2&nbsp;billion plus
interest, punitive damages, attorneys&#146; fees, and costs. Finally, the complaint includes an
objection to Southern Company&#146;s pending claims against Mirant in the Bankruptcy Court (which
relate to reimbursement under the separation agreements of payments such as income taxes,
interest, legal fees, and other guarantees described in Note 7 to the financial statements
of Southern Company in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form&nbsp;10- K) and seeks equitable subordination of
Southern Company&#146;s claims to the claims of all other creditors. Southern Company served an
answer to the complaint in April&nbsp;2007.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 6%">In January&nbsp;2006, the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Texas granted Southern
Company&#146;s motion to withdraw this action from the Bankruptcy Court and, in February&nbsp;2006,
granted Southern Company&#146;s motion to transfer the case to the U.S. District Court for the
Northern District of Georgia. In May&nbsp;2006, Southern Company filed a motion for summary
judgment seeking entry of judgment against the plaintiff as to all counts of the complaint.
In December&nbsp;2006, the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Georgia granted in
part and denied in part the motion. As a result, certain breach of fiduciary duty claims
alleged in earlier versions of the complaint are barred; all other claims in the complaint
may proceed. Southern Company believes there is no meritorious basis for the claims in the
complaint and is vigorously defending itself in this action. However, the final outcome of
this matter cannot now be determined.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 6%"><I>Mirant Securities Litigation</I></DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 6%">In November&nbsp;2002, Southern Company, certain former and current senior officers of Southern
Company, and 12 underwriters of Mirant&#146;s initial public offering were added as defendants in
a class action lawsuit that several Mirant shareholders originally filed against Mirant and
certain Mirant officers in May&nbsp;2002. Several other similar lawsuits filed subsequently were
consolidated into this litigation in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of
Georgia. The amended complaint is based on allegations related to alleged improper energy
trading and marketing activities involving the California energy market, alleged false
statements and omissions in Mirant&#146;s prospectus for its initial public offering and in
subsequent public statements by Mirant, and accounting-related issues previously disclosed
by Mirant. The lawsuit purports to include persons who acquired Mirant securities between
September&nbsp;26, 2000 and September&nbsp;5, 2002.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 6%">In July&nbsp;2003, the court dismissed all claims based on Mirant&#146;s alleged improper energy
trading and marketing activities involving the California energy market. The other claims
do not allege any improper trading and marketing activity, accounting errors, or material
misstatements or omissions on the part of Southern Company but seek to impose liability on
Southern Company based on allegations that Southern Company was a &#147;control person&#148; as to
Mirant prior to the spin-off date. Southern Company filed an answer to the consolidated
amended class action complaint in September&nbsp;2003. Plaintiffs have also filed a motion for
class certification.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 6%">During Mirant&#146;s Chapter&nbsp;11 proceeding, the securities litigation was stayed, with the
exception of limited discovery. Since Mirant&#146;s plan of reorganization has become effective,
the stay has been
lifted. In March&nbsp;2006, the plaintiffs filed a motion for reconsideration requesting that
the court vacate that portion of its July&nbsp;2003 order dismissing the plaintiffs&#146; claims based
upon Mirant&#146;s alleged
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->114<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>NOTES TO THE CONDENSED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS: (Continued)</B>
</DIV>



<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 6%">improper energy trading and marketing activities involving the California energy market.
Southern Company and the other defendants have opposed the plaintiffs&#146; motion. On March&nbsp;6,
2007, the court granted plaintiffs&#146; motion for reconsideration, reinstated the California
energy market claims, and
granted in part and denied in part defendants&#146; motion to compel certain class certification
discovery. On March&nbsp;21, 2007, defendants filed renewed motions to dismiss the California
energy claims on grounds originally set forth in their 2003 motions to dismiss, but which
were not addressed by the court. On July&nbsp;27, 2007, certain defendants, including Southern
Company, filed motions for reconsideration of the court&#146;s denial of a motion seeking
dismissal of certain federal securities laws claims based upon, among other things, certain
alleged errors included in financial statements issued by Mirant. The ultimate outcome of
this matter cannot be determined at this time.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 6%">The plaintiffs have also stated that they intend to request that the court grant leave for
them to amend the complaint to add allegations based upon claims asserted against Southern
Company in the MC Asset Recovery litigation.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 6%">Under certain circumstances, Southern Company will be obligated under its Bylaws to
indemnify the four current and/or former Southern Company officers who served as directors
of Mirant at the time of its initial public offering through the date of the spin-off and
who are also named as defendants in this lawsuit. The final outcome of this matter cannot
now be determined.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 6%"><B>Environmental Matters</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 6%"><I>New Source Review Actions</I></DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 6%">In November&nbsp;1999, the EPA brought a civil action in the U.S. District Court for the Northern
District of Georgia against certain Southern Company subsidiaries, including Alabama Power
and Georgia Power, alleging that these subsidiaries had violated the NSR provisions of the
Clean Air Act and related state laws at certain coal-fired generating facilities. Through
subsequent amendments and other legal procedures, the EPA filed a separate action in January
2001 against Alabama Power in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Alabama
after Alabama Power was dismissed from the original action. In these lawsuits, the EPA
alleged that NSR violations occurred at eight coal-fired generating facilities operated by
Alabama Power and Georgia Power, including one co-owned by Mississippi Power. The civil
actions request penalties and injunctive relief, including an order requiring the
installation of the best available control technology at the affected units. The EPA
concurrently issued notices of violations relating to Gulf Power&#146;s Plant Crist and a unit
partially owned by Gulf Power at Plant Scherer. In early 2000, the EPA filed a motion to
amend its complaint to add the allegations in the notice of violation and to add Gulf Power
as a defendant. However, in March&nbsp;2001, the Court denied the motion based on lack of
jurisdiction, and the EPA has not refiled. The action against Georgia Power has been
administratively closed since the spring of 2001, and the case has not been reopened.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 6%">In June&nbsp;2006, the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Alabama entered a consent
decree between Alabama Power and the EPA, resolving the alleged NSR violations at Plant
Miller. The consent decree required Alabama Power to pay $100,000 to resolve the
government&#146;s claim for a civil penalty and to donate $4.9&nbsp;million of sulfur dioxide emission
allowances to a nonprofit charitable organization and formalized specific emissions
reductions to be accomplished by Alabama Power, consistent with other Clean Air Act programs
that require emissions reductions. In August&nbsp;2006, the district court in Alabama granted
Alabama Power&#146;s motion for summary judgment and entered final judgment in favor of Alabama
Power on the EPA&#146;s claims related to all of the remaining plants: Plants Barry, Gaston,
Gorgas, and Greene County.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->115<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>


<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>NOTES TO THE CONDENSED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS: (Continued)</B>
</DIV>



<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 6%">The plaintiffs appealed the district court&#146;s decision to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the
Eleventh Circuit, and the appeal was stayed by the Appeals Court pending the U.S. Supreme
Court&#146;s decision in a similar case against Duke Energy. The Supreme Court issued its
decision in the Duke Energy case in April&nbsp;2007. On October&nbsp;5, 2007, the U.S. District Court
for the Northern District of Alabama issued an order in the Alabama Power case indicating a
willingness to re-evaluate its previous
decision in light of the Supreme Court&#146;s Duke Energy opinion. On December&nbsp;21, 2007, the
Eleventh Circuit vacated the district court&#146;s decision in the Alabama Power case and
remanded the case back to the district court for consideration of the legal issues in light
of the Supreme Court&#146;s decision in the Duke Energy case. The final outcome of these matters
cannot be determined at this time.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 6%">Southern Company and the traditional operating companies believe they complied with
applicable laws and the EPA regulations and interpretations in effect at the time the work
in question took place. The Clean Air Act authorizes maximum civil penalties of $25,000 to
$32,500 per day, per violation at each generating unit, depending on the date of the alleged
violation. An adverse outcome in either of these cases could require substantial capital
expenditures or affect the timing of currently budgeted capital expenditures that cannot be
determined at this time and could possibly require payment of substantial penalties. Such
expenditures could affect future results of operations, cash flows, and financial condition
if such costs are not recovered through regulated rates.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 6%"><I>Carbon Dioxide Litigation</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 6%"><I>New York Case</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 6%">In July&nbsp;2004, attorneys general from eight states, each outside of Southern Company&#146;s
service territory, and the corporation counsel for New York City filed a complaint in the
U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York against Southern Company and four
other electric power companies. A nearly identical complaint was filed by three
environmental groups in the same court. The complaints allege that the companies&#146; emissions
of carbon dioxide, a greenhouse gas, contribute to global warming, which the plaintiffs
assert is a public nuisance. Under common law public and private nuisance theories, the
plaintiffs seek a judicial order (1)&nbsp;holding each defendant jointly and severally liable for
creating, contributing to, and/or maintaining global warming and (2)&nbsp;requiring each of the
defendants to cap its emissions of carbon dioxide and then reduce those emissions by a
specified percentage each year for at least a decade. Plaintiffs have not, however,
requested that damages be awarded in connection with their claims. Southern Company
believes these claims are without merit and notes that the complaint cites no statutory or
regulatory basis for the claims. In September&nbsp;2005, the U.S. District Court for the
Southern District of New York granted Southern Company&#146;s and the other defendants&#146; motions
to dismiss these cases. The plaintiffs filed an appeal to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the
Second Circuit in October&nbsp;2005 and no decision has been issued. The ultimate outcome of
these matters cannot be determined at this time.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 6%"><I>Kivalina Case</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 6%">On February&nbsp;26, 2008, the Native Village of Kivalina and the City of Kivalina filed a suit
in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against several electric
utilities (including Southern Company), several oil companies, and a coal company. The
plaintiffs are the governing bodies of an Inupiat village in Alaska. The plaintiffs contend
that the village is being destroyed by erosion allegedly caused by global warming that the
plaintiffs attribute to emissions of greenhouse gases by the defendants. The plaintiffs
assert claims for public and private nuisance and contend that the defendants have acted in
concert and are therefore jointly and severally liable for the plaintiffs&#146; damages. The
suit seeks damages for lost property values and for the cost of relocating the village,
which cost is alleged to be $95&nbsp;million to $400&nbsp;million. Southern Company believes that
these
claims are without merit and notes that the complaint cites no statutory or regulatory basis
for the claims. The ultimate outcome of this matter cannot be determined at this time.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->116<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>


<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>NOTES TO THE CONDENSED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS: (Continued)</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 6%"><B>Environmental Remediation</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 6%">The registrants must comply with other environmental laws and regulations that cover the
handling and disposal of waste and releases of hazardous substances. Under these various
laws and regulations, the subsidiaries may also incur substantial costs to clean up
properties. The traditional operating companies have each received authority from their
respective state PSCs to recover approved environmental compliance costs through regulatory
mechanisms. Within limits approved by the state PSCs, these rates are adjusted annually or
as necessary.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 6%">Georgia Power has been designated as a potentially responsible party at sites governed by
the Georgia Hazardous Site Response Act and/or by the federal Comprehensive Environmental
Response, Compensation, and Liability Act (CERCLA), including a large site in Brunswick,
Georgia on the CERCLA National Priorities List (NPL). The parties have completed the
removal of wastes from the Brunswick site as ordered by the EPA. Additional claims for
recovery of natural resource damages at this site or for the assessment and potential
cleanup of other sites on the Georgia Hazardous Sites Inventory and CERCLA NPL are
anticipated.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 6%">Gulf Power&#146;s environmental remediation liability includes estimated costs of environmental
remediation projects of approximately $66.9&nbsp;million as of March&nbsp;31, 2008. These estimated
costs relate to site closure criteria by the Florida Department of Environmental
Protection (FDEP)&nbsp;for impacts to groundwater from herbicide applications at Gulf Power
substations. The schedule for completion of the remediation projects will be subject to
FDEP approval. The projects have been approved by the Florida PSC for recovery through Gulf
Power&#146;s environmental cost recovery clause; therefore, there was no impact on net income as
a result of these estimates.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 6%">In 2003, the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality (TCEQ)&nbsp;designated Mississippi Power
as a potentially responsible party at a site in Texas. The site was owned by an electric
transformer company that handled Mississippi Power&#146;s transformers as well as those of many
other entities. The site owner is now in bankruptcy and the State of Texas has entered into
an agreement with Mississippi Power and several other utilities to investigate and remediate
the site. Amounts expensed during 2005, 2006, and 2007 related to this work were not
material. Hundreds of entities have received notices from the TCEQ requesting their
participation in the anticipated site remediation. The final outcome of this matter to
Mississippi Power will depend upon further environmental assessment and the ultimate number
of potentially responsible parties and cannot now
be determined. The remediation expenses incurred by Mississippi Power are expected to be
recovered through the ECO Plan. See Note 3 to the financial statements of Mississippi Power
under &#147;Retail Regulatory
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->117<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>NOTES TO THE CONDENSED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS: (Continued)</B>
</DIV>



<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 6%">Matters -Environmental Compliance Overview Plan&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for additional
information.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 6%">The final outcome of these matters cannot now be determined. However, based on the
currently known conditions at these sites and the nature and extent of activities relating
to these sites, Southern Company, Georgia Power, Gulf Power, and Mississippi Power do not believe that
additional liabilities, if any, at these sites would be material to their respective
financial statements.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 6%"><B>FERC Matters</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 6%"><I>Market-Based Rate Authority</I></DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 6%">Each of the traditional operating companies and Southern Power has authorization from the
FERC to sell power to non-affiliates, including short-term opportunity sales, at
market-based prices. Specific FERC approval must be obtained with respect to a market-based
contract with an affiliate.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 6%">In December&nbsp;2004, the FERC initiated a proceeding to assess Southern Company&#146;s generation
dominance within its retail service territory. The ability to charge market-based rates in
other markets is not an issue in the proceeding. Any new market-based rate sales by any
subsidiary of Southern Company in Southern Company&#146;s retail service territory entered into
during a 15-month refund period that ended in May&nbsp;2006 could be subject to refund to a
cost-based rate level.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 6%">In late June and July&nbsp;2007, hearings were held in this proceeding and the presiding
administrative law judge issued an initial decision on November&nbsp;9, 2007 regarding the
methodology to be used in the generation dominance tests. The proceedings are ongoing. The
ultimate outcome of this generation dominance proceeding cannot now be determined, but an
adverse decision by the FERC in a final order could require the traditional operating
companies and Southern Power to charge cost-based rates for certain wholesale sales in the
Southern Company retail service territory, which may be lower than negotiated market-based
rates and could also result in total refunds of up to $19.7&nbsp;million, plus interest. The
potential refunds include $3.9&nbsp;million for Alabama Power, $5.8&nbsp;million for Georgia Power,
$0.8&nbsp;million for Gulf Power, $8.4&nbsp;million for Mississippi Power, and $0.7&nbsp;million for
Southern Power, in each case plus interest. Southern Company and its subsidiaries believe
that there is no meritorious basis for this proceeding and are vigorously defending
themselves in this matter.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 6%">On June&nbsp;21, 2007, the FERC issued its final rule in Order No.&nbsp;697 regarding market-based
rate authority. The FERC generally retained its current market-based rate standards.
Responding to a number of requests for rehearing, the FERC issued Order No.&nbsp;697-A on April&nbsp;21,
2008. This latest order largely affirmed its prior revision and codification of the
regulations governing market-based rates for public utilities. The impact of these orders
and their effect on the generation dominance proceeding cannot now be determined.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 6%"><I>Intercompany Interchange Contract</I></DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 6%">Southern Company&#146;s generation fleet in its retail service territory is operated under the
IIC as approved by the FERC. In May&nbsp;2005, the FERC initiated a new proceeding to examine
(1)&nbsp;the provisions of the IIC among the traditional operating companies, Southern Power, and
SCS, as agent, under the terms of which the Power Pool is operated, (2)&nbsp;whether any parties
to the IIC have violated the FERC&#146;s standards of conduct applicable to utility companies
that are transmission providers, and (3)&nbsp;whether Southern Company&#146;s code of conduct defining
Southern Power as a &#147;system company&#148; rather than a &#147;marketing affiliate&#148; is just and
reasonable. In connection with the formation of
Southern Power, the FERC authorized Southern Power&#146;s inclusion in the IIC in 2000. The FERC
also previously approved Southern Company&#146;s code of conduct.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->118<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>


<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>NOTES TO THE CONDENSED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS: (Continued)</B>
</DIV>



<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 6%">In October&nbsp;2006, the FERC issued an order accepting a settlement resolving the proceeding
subject to Southern Company&#146;s agreement to accept certain modifications to the settlement&#146;s
terms and Southern Company notified the FERC that it accepted the modifications. The
modifications largely involve functional separation and information restrictions related to
marketing activities conducted on behalf of Southern Power. Southern Company filed with the
FERC in November&nbsp;2006 a compliance plan in connection with the order. On April&nbsp;19, 2007,
the FERC approved, with certain modifications, the plan submitted by Southern Company.
Implementation of the plan is not expected to have a material impact on the financial
statements of Southern Company or the traditional operating companies. Southern Power&#146;s
cost of implementing the compliance plan, including the modifications, is expected to be
approximately $8&nbsp;million annually. On November&nbsp;19, 2007, Southern Company notified the FERC
that the plan had been implemented and the FERC division of audits subsequently began an
audit pertaining to compliance implementation and related matters, which is ongoing.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 6%"><I>Generation Interconnection Agreements</I></DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 6%">In November&nbsp;2004, generator company subsidiaries of Tenaska, Inc. (Tenaska), as
counterparties to three previously executed interconnection agreements with subsidiaries of
Southern Company, filed complaints at the FERC requesting that the FERC modify the
agreements and that those Southern Company subsidiaries refund a total of $19&nbsp;million
previously paid for interconnection facilities of which $11&nbsp;million would be refunded by
Alabama Power and $8&nbsp;million by Georgia Power. No other similar complaints are pending with
the FERC.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 6%">On January&nbsp;19, 2007, the FERC issued an order granting Tenaska&#146;s requested relief. Although
the FERC&#146;s order required the modification of Tenaska&#146;s interconnection agreements, under
the provisions of the order, Southern Company determined that no refund was payable to
Tenaska. Southern Company requested rehearing asserting that the FERC retroactively applied
a new principle to existing interconnection agreements. Tenaska requested rehearing of
FERC&#146;s methodology for determining the amount of refunds. The requested rehearings were
denied, and Southern Company and Tenaska have appealed the orders to the U.S. Circuit Court
for the District of Columbia. The final outcome of this matter cannot now be determined.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 6%"><B>Right of Way Litigation</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 6%">Southern Company and certain of its subsidiaries, including Gulf Power, Mississippi Power,
and Southern Telecom, Inc. (a subsidiary of SouthernLINC Wireless), have been named as
defendants in numerous lawsuits brought by landowners since 2001. The plaintiffs&#146; lawsuits
claim that defendants may not use, or sublease to third parties, some or all of the fiber
optic communications lines on the rights of way that cross the plaintiffs&#146; properties and
that such actions exceed the easements or other property rights held by defendants. The
plaintiffs assert claims for, among other things, trespass and unjust enrichment and seek
compensatory and punitive damages and injunctive relief. Management of Southern Company and
its subsidiaries believe that they have complied with applicable laws and that the
plaintiffs&#146; claims are without merit.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 6%">In November&nbsp;2003, the Second Circuit Court in Gadsden County, Florida, ruled in favor of the
plaintiffs on their motion for partial summary judgment concerning liability in one such
lawsuit brought by landowners regarding the installation and use of fiber optic cable over
Gulf Power rights of way located on the landowners&#146; property. Subsequently, the plaintiffs
sought to amend their complaint and asked the court to enter a final declaratory judgment
and to enter an order enjoining Gulf Power from allowing expanded general telecommunications
use of the fiber optic cables that are the subject of this litigation. In January&nbsp;2005, the
trial court granted in part the plaintiffs&#146; motion to
amend their complaint and denied the requested declaratory and injunctive relief. In
November&nbsp;2005, the trial court ruled in favor of the plaintiffs and against Gulf Power on
their respective motions for
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->119<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>



<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>NOTES TO THE CONDENSED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS: (Continued)</B>
</DIV>



<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 6%">partial summary judgment. In that same order, the trial court also denied Gulf Power&#146;s
motion to dismiss certain claims. Gulf Power filed an appeal to the Florida First District
Court of Appeals in December&nbsp;2005. In October&nbsp;2006, the Florida First District Court of
Appeal issued an order dismissing Gulf Power&#146;s December&nbsp;2005 appeal on the basis that the
trial court&#146;s order was a non-final order and therefore not subject to review on appeal at
this time. The case was returned to the trial court for further proceedings. The parties
reached agreement on a proposed settlement plan that was subject to approval by the trial
court. On November&nbsp;7, 2007, the trial court granted preliminary approval and set forth the
requirements for the trial court to make its final determination on the proposed settlement.
At a hearing on April&nbsp;30, 2008, the trial court granted final approval of the settlement
agreement. The resulting order will become final and not subject to appeal 30&nbsp;days
following signature by the court.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 6%">To date, Mississippi Power has entered into agreements with plaintiffs in approximately 90%
of the actions pending against Mississippi Power to clarify its easement rights in the State
of Mississippi. These agreements have been approved by the Circuit Courts of Harrison
County and Jasper County, Mississippi (First Judicial Circuit), and dismissals of the
related cases are in progress. These agreements have not resulted in any material effects
on Southern Company&#146;s or Mississippi Power&#146;s financial statements.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 6%">In addition, in late 2001, certain subsidiaries of Southern Company, including Alabama
Power, Georgia Power, Gulf Power, Mississippi Power, and Southern Telecom, Inc. (a
subsidiary of SouthernLINC Wireless), were named as defendants in a lawsuit brought by a
telecommunications company that uses certain of the defendants&#146; rights of way. This lawsuit
alleges, among other things, that the defendants are contractually obligated to indemnify,
defend, and hold harmless the telecommunications company from any liability that may be
assessed against it in pending and future right of way litigation. The defendants believe
that the plaintiff&#146;s claims are without merit. In the fall of 2004, the trial court stayed
the case until resolution of the underlying landowner litigation discussed above. In
January&nbsp;2005, the Georgia Court of Appeals dismissed the telecommunications company&#146;s appeal
of the trial court&#146;s order for lack of jurisdiction. An adverse outcome in this matter,
combined with an adverse outcome against the telecommunications company in one or more of
the right of way lawsuits, could result in substantial judgments; however, the final outcome
of these matters cannot now be determined.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 6%"><B>Income Tax Matters</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 6%"><I>Leveraged Lease Transactions</I></DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 6%">See
Note 1 to the financial statements of Southern Company under &#147;Income and Other Taxes,&#148;
Note 3 to the financial statements of Southern Company under
&#147;Income Tax Matters,&#148; and Note
5 to the financial statements of Southern Company under &#147;Unrecognized Tax Benefits&#148; in Item
8 of the Form 10-K. The IRS challenged Southern Company&#146;s deductions related to three
international lease transactions (so-called SILO or sale-in-lease-out transactions), in
connection with its audits of Southern Company&#146;s 2000 through 2003 tax returns. In the
third quarter 2006, Southern Company paid the full amount of the disputed tax and the
applicable interest on the SILO issue for tax years 2000 &#150; 2001 and filed a claim for refund
which has now been denied by the IRS. The disputed tax amount is $79&nbsp;million and the related
interest is approximately $24&nbsp;million for these tax years. This payment, and the subsequent
IRS disallowance of the refund claim, closed the issue with the IRS and Southern Company has
initiated litigation in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Georgia for a
complete refund of tax and interest paid for the 2000 &#150; 2001 tax years. The IRS also
challenged the SILO deductions for the tax years 2002 and 2003. The estimated amount of
disputed tax and interest for these tax years was approximately $83&nbsp;million and $15&nbsp;million,
respectively. The
tax and interest for these tax years was paid to the IRS in the fourth quarter 2006.
Southern Company has accounted for both payments in 2006 as deposits. For tax years 2000
through 2007, Southern
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->120<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt">
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Company has claimed approximately $330&nbsp;million in tax benefits related to these SILO
transactions challenged by the IRS. These tax benefits relate to timing differences and do
not impact total net income over the life of the transactions. Southern Company believes these transactions are valid leases
for U.S. tax purposes and the related deductions are allowable. Southern Company is
continuing to pursue resolution of these matters; however, the ultimate outcome cannot now
be determined. In accordance with the requirements of FASB Interpretation No.&nbsp;48,
&#147;Accounting for Uncertainty in Income Taxes&#148; and FASB Staff Position No.&nbsp;13-2, &#147;Accounting
for a Change or Projected Change in the Timing of Cash Flows Relating to Income Taxes
Generated by a Leveraged Lease Transaction,&#148; Southern Company will continue to evaluate the
SILO transactions and the projected timing of income tax cash flows in light of Southern
Company&#146;s pending litigation, other recent court decisions involving lease-in-lease-out
(LILO)&nbsp;and SILO transactions, and proposed legislation. As a result, it is reasonably
possible that the amount of the unrecognized tax benefit could significantly change within
the next 12&nbsp;months. In addition, the U.S. Senate is currently considering legislation that
would disallow tax benefits after December&nbsp;31, 2007 for SILO losses and other international
leveraged lease transactions (such as LILO transactions). The ultimate impact
on Southern Company&#146;s net income and cash flow will be dependent on the outcome of the
pending litigation, other court decisions, and proposed legislation, but could be
significant, and potentially material.</TD>
</TR>

    <TD>Georgia Power&#146;s 2005 through 2007 income tax filings for the State of Georgia include state
income tax credits for increased activity through Georgia ports. Georgia Power has also
filed similar claims for the years 2002 through 2004. The Georgia Department of Revenue has
not responded to these claims. On July&nbsp;24, 2007, Georgia Power filed a complaint in the
Superior Court of Fulton County to recover the credits claimed for the years 2002 through
2004. If Georgia Power prevails, these claims could have a significant, and possibly
material, positive effect on Southern Company&#146;s and Georgia Power&#146;s net income. If Georgia
Power is not successful, payment of the related state tax could have a significant, and
possibly material, negative effect on Southern Company&#146;s and Georgia Power&#146;s cash flow. The
ultimate outcome of this matter cannot now be determined.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left"><B><I>&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD width="1%"><B><I>&nbsp;</I></B></TD>
    <TD><I>IRC Section&nbsp;199 Domestic Production Deduction</I></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>The American Jobs Creation Act of 2004 created a tax deduction for a portion of income
attributable to U.S. production activities as defined in the IRC Section&nbsp;199 (production
activities deduction). The deduction is equal to a stated percentage of qualified
production activities net income. The percentage is phased in over the years 2005 through
2010 with a 3% rate applicable to the years 2005 and 2006, a 6% rate applicable for years
2007 through 2009, and a 9% rate applicable for all years after 2009. The IRS has not
clearly defined a methodology for calculating this deduction, therefore an unrecognized tax
benefit has been recorded related to this deduction.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>On January&nbsp;1, 2008, the registrants adopted FASB Statement No.&nbsp;159, &#147;Fair Value Option
for Financial Assets and Financial Liabilities &#150; Including an Amendment of FASB Statement
No.&nbsp;115&#148; (SFAS No.&nbsp;159). This standard permits an entity to choose to measure many
financial instruments and certain other items at fair value. Southern Company, Alabama
Power, and Georgia Power have elected the fair value option only for investment
securities held in nuclear decommissioning trust funds (Funds). See Note 1 to the
financial statements of Southern Company, Alabama Power, and Georgia Power under &#147;Nuclear
Decommissioning&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for information on these trusts funds.</TD>
</TR>

fair value best represents the nature of the Funds. Management has delegated day-to-day
management of the investments in the Funds to unrelated third party managers with
oversight by Southern
</TD>

<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt"><TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">


</TABLE>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>NOTES TO THE CONDENSED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS: (Continued)</B>
</DIV>



<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 6%">Company, Alabama Power, and Georgia Power management. The managers of the Funds are
authorized, within broad limits, to actively buy and sell securities at their own
discretion in order to maximize the investment return on the Funds&#146; investments.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 6%">The adoption of SFAS No.&nbsp;159 had no impact on the results of operations, cash flows, or
financial condition of Southern Company, Alabama Power, and Georgia Power as all gains,
losses, and other-than-temporary impairments, whether realized or unrealized, continue to
be recorded through a regulatory liability. For the three months ended March&nbsp;31, 2008,
the reduction in fair value of the Funds was $33.2&nbsp;million and $39.9&nbsp;million for Alabama
Power and Georgia Power,<BR>
respectively, which includes reinvested interest and dividends, and which totals $73.1
million for Southern Company.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 6%">Also on January&nbsp;1, 2008, Southern Company, the traditional operating companies, and
Southern Power adopted SFAS No.&nbsp;157 which defines fair value, establishes a framework for
measuring fair value, and requires additional disclosures about fair value measurements.
The criterion that is set forth in this standard is applicable to fair value measurement
where it is permitted or required under other accounting pronouncements.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 6%">SFAS No.&nbsp;157 defines fair value as the exit price, which is the price that would be
received to sell an asset or paid to transfer a liability in an orderly transaction
between market participants at the measurement date. The fair value measurement is based
on inputs of observable and unobservable market data that a market participant would use
in pricing the asset or liability. The use of observable inputs is maximized where
available and the use of unobservable inputs is minimized for fair value measurement. As
a means to illustrate the inputs used, SFAS No.&nbsp;157 establishes a three-tier fair value
hierarchy that prioritizes inputs to valuation techniques used for fair value
measurement.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt">
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="8%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left"><B>&#149;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Level 1 consists of observable market data in an active market for identical
assets or liabilities.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="8%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left"><B>&#149;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Level 2 consists of observable market data, other than that included in Level
1, that is either directly or indirectly observable.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="8%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left"><B>&#149;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Level 3 consists of unobservable market data. The input may reflect the
assumptions of the registrant of what a market participant would use in pricing
an asset or liability. If there is little available market data, then the
registrant&#146;s own assumptions are the best available information.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 6%">In the case of multiple inputs being used in a fair value measurement, the lowest level
input that is significant to the fair value measurement represents the level in the fair
value hierarchy in which the fair value measurement is reported.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 6%">The adoption of SFAS No.&nbsp;157 has not resulted in any significant changes to the
methodologies used for fair value measurement. Primarily all the changes in the fair
value of assets and liabilities are recorded in other comprehensive income or regulatory
assets and liabilities, and thus the impact on earnings is limited to derivatives that do
not qualify for hedge accounting. See Note 1 to the financial statements of Southern
Company, Alabama Power, and Georgia Power under &#147;Nuclear Decommissioning&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of
the Form 10-K for additional information and Note 6 to the financial statements of the
registrants in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for information on financial instruments.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->122<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>NOTES TO THE CONDENSED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS: (Continued)</B>
</DIV>



<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 6%">Energy-related derivatives and interest rate derivatives significantly comprise
over-the-counter contracts. The nuclear decommissioning trust funds are invested in a
diversified mix of equity and fixed income securities. &#147;Other&#148; represents marketable
securities and funds set aside to fund deferred compensation for certain management and
are also invested in various marketable securities. All of these financial instruments
and investments are valued primarily using the market approach.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 6%">Changes in the fair value measurement of the Level 3 items during the period are as
follows:
</DIV>
<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 6%">
<TABLE style="font-size: 10pt" cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="94%">

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt">
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">(D)</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>CONSTRUCTION PROJECTS</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left"><B>&nbsp;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%"><B>&nbsp;</B></TD>
    <TD><B>Construction Program</B></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>In connection with Georgia Power&#146;s entering into an engineering, procurement, and
construction agreement to design, engineer, procure, construct, and test two AP 1000 nuclear
units with electric generating capacity of approximately 1,100 MWs each and related
facilities, structures, and improvements at Plant Vogtle, the revised estimated total
construction program for Southern Company is $4.4&nbsp;billion in 2008, $5.2&nbsp;billion in 2009, and
$4.8&nbsp;billion in 2010 and for Georgia Power is $2.0&nbsp;billion in 2008, $2.6&nbsp;billion in 2009,
and $2.5&nbsp;billion in 2010. Actual construction costs may vary from these estimates because
of changes in such factors as: business conditions; environmental statutes and regulations;
nuclear plant regulation; FERC rules and regulations; load projections; the cost and
efficiency of construction labor, equipment, and materials; and the cost of capital. In
addition, there can be no assurance that costs related to capital expenditures will be fully
recovered. See Note 7 to the financial statements of Southern Company and Georgia Power
under &#147;COMMITMENTS &#151; Construction Program&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for additional
information.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left"><B>&nbsp;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%"><B>&nbsp;</B></TD>
    <TD><B>Kemper County Integrated Coal Gasification Combined Cycle</B></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>As part of the evaluation and screening of alternatives to meet its future generation needs,
Mississippi Power is considering the construction of an advanced coal gasification facility
to be located in Kemper County, Mississippi, that would use locally mined lignite coal. The
plant would use an air-blown IGCC technology that generates power from low-rank coals and
coals with high moisture or high ash content. These coals, which include lignite, make up
approximately half the proven United States and worldwide coal reserves. The feasibility
assessment of the project is currently underway. Mississippi Power filed an application in
June&nbsp;2006 with the DOE for certain tax credits available to projects using clean coal
technologies under the Energy Policy Act of 2005. The DOE subsequently certified the
project and in November&nbsp;2006, the IRS allocated IRC Section&nbsp;48A tax credits of $133&nbsp;million
to Mississippi Power. The utilization of these credits is dependent upon meeting the
certification requirements for the project, including an in-service date no later than
November&nbsp;2013. On February&nbsp;14, 2008, Mississippi Power also requested that the DOE transfer
the
remaining funds previously granted to another Southern Company project that would have been
located in Orlando, Florida. The Orlando project was cancelled in 2007.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->124<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>





<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>NOTES TO THE CONDENSED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS: (Continued)</B>
</DIV>


<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt">
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>In December&nbsp;2006, the Mississippi PSC approved Mississippi Power&#146;s request for accounting
treatment of the costs associated with Mississippi Power&#146;s generation resource planning,
evaluation, and screening activities. The Mississippi PSC gave Mississippi Power the
authority to create and recognize a regulatory asset for such costs. In December&nbsp;2007,
Mississippi Power reported to the Mississippi PSC an updated estimate and received an order
directing Mississippi Power to continue charging all costs associated with the generation
capacity assessment to the regulatory asset. At March&nbsp;31, 2008, Mississippi Power had spent
$25.3&nbsp;million, of which $2.7&nbsp;million related to land purchases capitalized. The retail
portion of $16.4&nbsp;million was deferred in other regulatory assets and the wholesale portion
of $6.2&nbsp;million was expensed. The retail portion of these costs will be charged to and
remain as a regulatory asset until the Mississippi PSC determines the prudence and ultimate
recovery of such costs, which decision is expected by January&nbsp;2009. The balance of such
regulatory asset is included in Mississippi Power&#146;s rate base for retail ratemaking
purposes. Approval by various regulatory agencies, including the Mississippi PSC, will also
be required if the project proceeds. The Mississippi PSC, in its discretion, may exercise
its additional rate authority granted to the Mississippi PSC in the Mississippi base load
construction legislation if such legislation is signed by the Governor and if the project
proceeds.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>The final outcome of this matter cannot now be determined.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">(E)</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>COMMON STOCK</TD>
</TR>

is attributable to exercised options and outstanding options under the stock option plan.

further information on the stock option plan. The effect of the stock options was

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>



<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>NOTES TO THE CONDENSED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS: (Continued)</B>
</DIV>



<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 6%">For the three months ended March&nbsp;31, 2008, the unrealized loss recognized in income for
energy-related derivative contracts that are not hedges was $14.0&nbsp;million for Southern
Company, $14.4&nbsp;million for Southern Power, and immaterial for all other registrants. For
the three months ended March&nbsp;31, 2007, the unrealized gain/loss recognized in income was
immaterial for all registrants.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 6%">The amounts reclassified from other comprehensive income to revenue and fuel expense for the
three months ended March&nbsp;31, 2008 and 2007 were immaterial for each registrant.
Additionally, no material ineffectiveness has been recorded in net income for the three
months ended March&nbsp;31, 2008 and 2007. The amounts expected to be reclassified from other
comprehensive income to revenue for the next twelve-month period to March&nbsp;31, 2009 are
losses of $10.9&nbsp;million for Southern Company, $2.5&nbsp;million for Mississippi Power, and $7.8
million for Southern Power and are immaterial for all other registrants. All other expected
reclassifications to income are immaterial for each registrant.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 6%">During 2007, Southern Company had derivatives in place to reduce its exposure to a phase-out
of certain income tax credits related to synthetic fuel production in 2007. In accordance
with Section&nbsp;45K of the IRC, these tax credits were subject to limitation as the annual
average price of oil increases. These derivatives settled on January&nbsp;1, 2008 and thus there
was no income statement impact in the three months ended March&nbsp;31, 2008. For the three
months ended March&nbsp;31, 2007, the fair value gain recognized in income to mark the
derivatives to market was $6.4&nbsp;million.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 6%">At March&nbsp;31, 2008, Southern Company had $1.8&nbsp;billion notional amount of interest rate
derivatives outstanding with net fair value losses of $30&nbsp;million as follows:
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 6%"><B><I>Cash Flow Hedges</I></B>

 </DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 6%">Subsequent
to March&nbsp;31, 2008, Gulf Power entered into a $110 million term
loan agreement that bears interest based on one-month LIBOR and
borrowed $80 million under such agreement. In connection with the
term loan agreement, Gulf Power terminated $80 million of interest
rate derivative contracts at a loss of $5.2 million. Gulf Power plans to
borrow the remaining $30 million under the term loan agreement in
June&nbsp;2008.</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 6%">The amounts reclassified from other comprehensive income to interest expense for the
three-month period ending March&nbsp;31, 2008 were a loss of $4.6&nbsp;million for Southern Company,
$3.5&nbsp;million for Southern Power, and immaterial for all other registrants. For the three
months ended March&nbsp;31, 2007, the losses reclassified to interest expense were $3.5&nbsp;million
for Southern Company, $3.3&nbsp;million for Southern Power, and immaterial for all other
registrants. No material ineffectiveness has been recorded in net income for any of the
periods reported.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->126<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">(G)</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>RETIREMENT BENEFITS</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Southern Company accounts for pension and other postretirement obligations in accordance
with SFAS No.&nbsp;158, &#147;Employers&#146; Accounting for Defined Benefit Pension and Other
Postretirement Plans&#148;&#151;an amendment of FASB Statements No.&nbsp;87, 88, 106, and 132(R) (SFAS No.
158). SFAS No.&nbsp;158 requires recognition of an asset for a plan&#146;s over funded status or a
liability for a plan&#146;s under funded status in Southern Company&#146;s statement of financial
position. In addition, the measurement date (the date at which plan assets and the benefit
obligation are measured) is required to be the same as Southern Company&#146;s fiscal year end.
As permitted, Southern Company adopted the measurement date provisions of SFAS No.&nbsp;158
effective January&nbsp;1, 2008. Southern Company&#146;s pension and postretirement plans previously
used a September&nbsp;30 measurement date. All plans are now measured as of December&nbsp;31,
consistent with Southern Company&#146;s fiscal year end. The adoption of the measurement date
provisions of SFAS No.&nbsp;158 increased long-term liabilities by approximately $28&nbsp;million and
prepaid pension costs by approximately $16&nbsp;million. There was no effect on Southern
Company&#146;s results of operations or cash flows.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">

    <TD align="right">&#151;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="right">$</TD>
    <TD align="right">1</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size: 1px">
    <TD colspan="21" align="left" style="border-top: 3px double #000000">&nbsp;</TD>

<!-- End Table Body -->
</TABLE>
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->127<!-- /Folio -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt">
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">(H)</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>EFFECTIVE TAX RATES</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Southern Company&#146;s effective tax rate was 32.2% for the three months ended March&nbsp;31,2008, as
compared to 30.8% for the same period in 2007. The increase was largely due to the
unavailability of synthetic fuel tax credits in 2008. See Note 5 to the financial
statements of each registrant in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for
information on the effective income tax rate. Southern Company recorded net synthetic fuel tax credits for the
three months ended March&nbsp;31, 2008 that are $23.9&nbsp;million less than the net synthetic fuel
tax credits recorded for the same period in 2007, which resulted in an increase in income
tax expense. The credits are not allowed under IRC Section&nbsp;45K for any production after
December&nbsp;31, 2007. The increase in Southern Company&#146;s effective tax rate was partially
offset by decreases in the effective tax rate at all of the other registrants. These
decreases were due to additional allowance for equity funds used during construction (which
is not taxable) recorded by Alabama Power, Georgia Power, and Gulf Power and by an increase
in the production activities deduction.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">(I)</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>NUCLEAR FUEL DISPOSAL COST LITIGATION</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>See Note 1 to the financial statements of Southern Company, Alabama Power, and Georgia Power
under &#147;Nuclear Fuel Disposal Costs&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for information regarding the
litigation brought by Alabama Power and Georgia Power against the government for breach of
contracts related to the disposal of spent nuclear fuel. On July&nbsp;9, 2007, the U.S. Court of
Federal Claims awarded Georgia Power a total of $30&nbsp;million, based on its ownership
interests, and awarded Alabama Power $17.3&nbsp;million, representing all of the direct costs of
the expansion of spent nuclear fuel storage facilities from 1998 through 2004. In August
2007, the government filed a motion for reconsideration, which was denied on November&nbsp;1,
2007. On January&nbsp;2, 2008, the government filed a notice of appeal. On February&nbsp;29, 2008,
the government filed a motion to stay the appeal pending the court&#146;s decisions in three
other cases already on appeal. On April&nbsp;1, 2008, the court granted the government&#146;s motion
to stay the appeal. A claim against the government was also filed for damages incurred
after December&nbsp;31, 2004 (the court-mandated cut-off in the original claim), due to the
government&#146;s continuing breach of contract. This claim was filed without including any
dollar amount for recovery of damages. The final outcome of this matter cannot be
determined at this time, but no material impact on net income is expected as any damage
amounts collected from the government are expected to be returned to customers.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->128<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>



<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>NOTES TO THE CONDENSED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS: (Continued)</B>
</DIV>


<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt">
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">(J)</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>SOUTHERN POWER DEPRECIATION STUDY</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Southern Power revised its depreciation rates in January&nbsp;2008. This change in estimate
arises from changes in useful life assumptions of certain components of plant in service
based on an engineering study completed in the first quarter 2008. Depreciation rates by
generating facility changed from a range of 2.7% to 3.8% to a range of 1.8% to 4.1%. These
changes increase depreciation and reduce net income. As a result of these changes, net
income was decreased by $0.7&nbsp;million for the first quarter 2008. The expected total impact
on Southern Power&#146;s net income for 2008 is a decrease of $2.8&nbsp;million.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">(K)</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>SEGMENT AND RELATED INFORMATION</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Southern Company&#146;s reportable business segments are the sale of electricity in the Southeast
by the traditional operating companies and Southern Power. The &#147;All Other&#148; column includes
parent Southern Company, which does not allocate operating expenses to business segments.
Also, this category includes segments below the quantitative threshold for separate
disclosure. These segments include investments in leveraged lease projects,
telecommunications, and energy-related services. Southern Power&#146;s revenues from sales to
the traditional operating companies were $133&nbsp;million and $110&nbsp;million for the three months
ended March&nbsp;31, 2008 and March&nbsp;31, 2007, respectively. All other intersegment revenues are
not material. Financial data for business segments and products and services are as
follows:</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>
</DIV>

involved.

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 3%">See RISK FACTORS in Item&nbsp;1A of the Form 10-K for a discussion of the risk factors of
Southern Company and the subsidiary registrants. There have been no material changes to
these risk factors from those previously disclosed in the Form 10-K.
